{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox artifact | name = | image = [[File:Chalcolithic leather shoe from Areni-1 cave.jpg|150px]] | image2 = | image_caption = | material = | size = | writing = | created = | discovered = | discovered_place = [[Areni-1 cave]], Armenia | discovered_coords = | discovered_date = 2008 | discovered_by = | location = [[History Museum of Armenia]] | id = | map = | website = }}
The '''Areni-1 shoe''' is a 5,500-year-old [[leather]] shoe that was found in 2008 in excellent condition in the [[Areni-1 cave]] located in the [[Vayots Dzor Province|Vayots Dzor]] province of [[Armenia]].<ref name="National Geographic">{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2010/06/09/worlds-oldest-leather-shoe-found-in-armenia-2/ |title=World's Oldest Leather Shoe Found—Stunningly Preserved |last=Dindar |first=Shereen |work=National Post |location=Canada |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 11, 2010}}</ref> It is a one-piece leather-hide shoe, the oldest piece of leather footwear in the world known to contemporary researchers.<!-- the range of accuracy in dating methods may have quite a large variable, depending upon what is stated for this dating, it could make little difference that a few hundred years difference is claimed and make the find merely contemporary with that found in Germany --> The discovery was made by an international team led by [[Boris Gasparyan]], an archaeologist from the Institute of Archaeology and Ethnography of the [[National Academy of Sciences of Armenia]] (co-directors of the project are [[Ron Pinhasi]] from [[University College Cork]] in [[Ireland]], and [[Gregory Areshian]] from [[UCLA]]).<ref>{{cite news |title=Ancient shoe steps out of cave and into limelight |author=Bruce Bower |newspaper=Science News |date=July 3, 2010 |url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/60099/title/Ancient_shoe_steps_out_of_cave_and_into_limelight |accessdate=September 8, 2010}}</ref>
==Discovery== An Armenian post-graduate student, [[Diana Zardaryan]], discovered the leather shoe in the course of excavations by a team of archeologists from Armenia’s [[Institute of Archaeology and Ethnography]], Ireland and the United States.<ref name="ArmLib-June12-2010">[http://www.azatutyun.am/content/article/2069047.html ''Oldest Leather Shoe A ‘Dream’ Find For Armenian Scientist''], Armenia Liberty ([[RFE/RL]]), June 12, 2010.</ref> The shoe was found upside down at the base of a shallow, rounded, and plastered pit that was {{convert|45|cm|abbr=on}} deep and {{convert|44|–|48|cm|abbr=on}} wide, beneath an overturned broken [[Chalcolithic]] ceramic bowl.<ref name="First Direct Evidence of Chalcolithic Footwear from the Near Eastern Highlands">{{cite news |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0010984 |title=First Direct Evidence of Chalcolithic Footwear from the Near Eastern Highlands |work=PLOS One |first1=Ron |last1=Pinhasi |first2=Boris |last2=Gasparian |first3=Gregory |last3=Areshian |first4=Diana |last4=Zardaryan |first5=Alexia |last5=Smith |first6=Guy |last6=Bar-Oz |first7=Thomas |last7=Higham |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 9, 2010}}</ref> A broken pot and goat horns also were found nearby. Excavations in the same area also found [[Areni-1 winery|the world's oldest wine-making site]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12158341 |title='Oldest known wine-making facility' found in Armenia. |accessdate=January 11, 2011 |work=BBC |date=January 11, 2011}}</ref>
The research was funded by the [[National Geographic Society]], the [[Chitjian Foundation]], the [[Gfoeller Foundation]], the [[Steinmetz Family Foundation]], the [[Boochever Foundation]] and the [[Cotsen Institute of Archaeology]] at [[UCLA]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/10/oldest-leather-shoe-steps_n_607264.html |title=Oldest Leather Shoe Steps Out After 5,500 Years |work=Huffington Post}}</ref> The team's findings were published on June 9, 2010, in the journal ''[[PLOS One]]''.
==Analysis== The shoe was found in near-perfect condition due to the cool and dry conditions in the cave and a thick layer of sheep dung which acted as a solid seal. Large storage containers were found in the same cave, many of which held well-preserved wheat, barley, and [[apricot]]s, as well as other edible plants.<ref name="Fox"/> The shoe contained grass and the archaeologists were uncertain as to whether this was because the grass was used as insulation to keep the foot warm, or used to preserve the shape of the shoe while not being worn. Lead archaeologist Ron Pinhasi could not determine whether the shoe belonged to a man or a woman. While small, approximately a woman's U.S. and Canada size 7, European size 37, or UK size 6, he stated that "the shoe could well have fitted a man from that era".<ref name="Fox"/> The [[shoe laces]] were preserved as well.<ref name="Fox"/>
Major similarities exist between the manufacturing technique and style of one-piece leather-hide shoes discovered across Europe and the one reported from Areni-1 Cave, suggesting that shoes of this type were worn for millennia across a large and environmentally diverse geographic region.<ref name="First Direct Evidence of Chalcolithic Footwear from the Near Eastern Highlands"/> According to Pinhasi, the Areni-1 shoe is similar to the Irish ''[[pampooties]]'', a shoe style worn in the [[Aran Islands]] up to the 1950s.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i8KRXbqACR1CdoIW6YN9-GE4GjxQ | title = 5,500-year leather mocassin world's oldest shoe |agency=AFP | date = June 10, 2010 | accessdate = June 12, 2010}}</ref> The shoes are very similar to the traditional shoes of the Balkans, still seen today in festivals, known as [[Opanci]] (''Opanke'').<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/06/100609-worlds-oldest-leather-shoe-armenia-science/ National Geographic: ''World's Oldest Leather Shoe Found—Stunningly Preserved'']</ref>
When the material was dated by the two radiocarbon laboratories in [[Oxford]] and California, it was established that the shoe dates back to 3,500 B.C.<!-- the variable should be given as =/- xxx years --> This date is a few hundred years older than the date given for the leather shoe found on [[Ötzi the Iceman]], 400 years older than those found at [[Stonehenge]], and 1,000 years older than those found at the [[Great Pyramid of Giza]].<ref name="Fox">{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2010/06/09/oldest-leather-shoe-archaeology/ |title=What's Older Than the Pyramids and Smells Worse Than a Mummy? |publisher=Fox News |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 9, 2010}}</ref>
After having been treated for preservation, the Areni-1 shoe is on display at the [[History Museum of Armenia]], Yerevan.<ref name="ArmeniaNow.com">{{cite news |url=http://armenianow.com/arts_and_culture/23683/ancient_shoe_found_armenia/ |title=Do You Have that in a Size 38?: World’s oldest shoe to go on display in Yerevan |last=Gevorgyan |first=Siranuysh |work=ArmeniaNow.com |date=June 14, 2010 |accessdate=June 14, 2010}}</ref>

{{Expand Spanish|Inmigración argentina en México|topic=cult|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Argentine Mexican
''argentino-mexicano'' |image= |caption= |population = '''19,214''' Argentina-born residents (2017){{cite web|title=Table 1: Total migrant stock at mid-year by origin and by major area, region, country or area of destination, 2017|url=http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/migration/data/estimates2/data/UN_MigrantStockByOriginAndDestination_2017.xlsx|publisher=United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division |accessdate=17 August 2018}}
Unknown number of Mexicans of Argentine descent |rels=[[Christianity]] • [[Judaism]] |related = Argentine diaspora ([[Argentine American]] • [[Argentine Australian]] • [[Argentines in Spain|Argentine Spaniard]] • [[Argentine Brazilian]]) }} There is a significant '''Argentine diaspora in Mexico'''. According to the 2010 census, there were 13,696 registered [[Argentine people|Argentine citizens]] living in Mexico,{{cite web|url=http://www.inegi.gob.mx/inegi/contenidos/espanol/prensa/contenidos/Articulos/sociodemograficas/nacidosenotropais.pdf |title=Conociendonos todos |publisher=INEGI |accessdate=October 30, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427100913/http://www.inegi.gob.mx/inegi/contenidos/espanol/prensa/contenidos/Articulos/sociodemograficas/nacidosenotropais.pdf |archivedate=April 27, 2013 }} an increase from the 6,465 registered in the 2000 census. Argentine immigrants constitute the second largest community of South Americans in Mexico (after [[Colombian Mexican]]s) and the fifth largest immigrant community overall. The Argentine-Mexican community is sometimes known as '''ArgenMex'''.{{cite web|title=Los argenmex y la fiesta patria argentina en México|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/entretenimiento/2014/07/06/argenmex-fiesta-patria-argentina-mexico|publisher=El Economista|accessdate=25 January 2016}} ==History== {{multiple image | direction = horizontal | width = | header = | align = left | image1 = Juan Gelman -presidenciagovar- 31JUL07.jpg | width1 = 175 | caption1 = [[Juan Gelman]], [[Cervantes Prize]]-winning poet that first arrived in Mexico as an exile of the Military Junta | image2 = EnriqueDussel.jpg | width2 = 138 | caption2 = [[Enrique Dussel]], writer and philosopher forced into exile following a bombing at his home by a military group }} Argentines have been in Mexico since at least the 1895 census, and periodic migration has continued following the ebb and flow of the [[Argentine economy]]. Both countries share the [[Spanish language]]; their historical origins are common (part of the [[Spanish Empire]]). With two main emigrant waves; during the [[Dirty War|1970s Dirty War]] and after the [[1998–2002 Argentine great depression|2001 economic crisis]]. The largest Argentine community is in [[Mexico City]] (with a sizeable congregation in the [[Condesa]] neighborhood) and there are smaller communities in Leon, Guadalajara, Puebla, Cancun, Playa del Carmen, Tulum, Mérida, Monterrey and Tampico. Most Argentines established in Mexico come from the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, Cordoba and Tucuman. The Argentine community has participated in the opening of establishments such as restaurants, bars, boutiques, modeling consultants, foreign exchange interbank markets, among other lines of business. ==Culture== {{multiple image | direction = horizontal | width = | header = | align = right | image1 = Libertad Lamarque.jpg | width1 = 150 | caption1 = [[Libertad Lamarque]], actress and singer of the [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema]] | image2 = GuillermoFranco0410.JPG | width2 = 141 | caption2 = [[Guillermo Franco]], footballer that played on the [[Mexico national football team|Mexico national team]] }} Argentine actors have an important presence in Mexico's [[Television in Mexico|television industry]]. Frequently, actors arrive in Mexico to learn [[neutral Spanish]] (based on Mexican Spanish and used for mass media distributed across Latin America, such as dubbed foreign films,) and remain as they find work with one of the country's major television networks. Notable among these actors are the telenovela ''galanes'' (male leads) [[Juan Soler]] and [[Sebastian Rulli]]. In the music industry, prominent Argentine-Mexicans include [[Amanda Miguel]], [[Fey (singer)|Fey]] and [[Noel Schajris]]. There has been controversy in Mexico over the inclusion of naturalized Mexicans (especially Argentine-Mexicans) on [[Mexico national football team|Mexico's national football team]].{{cite web|title=Naturalizados asaltan el Tri|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/notas-online/deportes/2009/01/20/tri-las-selecciones-mas-naturalizadas-planeta|publisher=El Economista|accessdate=6 March 2015}} The arguments range from [[xenophobic]] ideas to the belief that Argentines have been granted citizenship in order to be eligible players on the team. Nonetheless, Argentines wanting to attain Mexican citizenship have to do so through meeting naturalization and residency requirements. ==See also== *[[Argentina–Mexico relations]] {{Portal|Mexico|Argentina}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://youtube.com/watch?v=J0GqZ5QkYbM Los que llegaron - Argentinos] from [[Canal Once]] (In Spanish) {{Argentine diaspora}} {{Ethnic groups in Mexico}} [[Category:Argentine emigrants to Mexico| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mexico]] [[Category:Argentine diaspora|Mexico]] [[Category:Immigration to Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican people of Argentine descent| ]]

In [[precolumbian]] [[Aztec society]], a '''calpulli''' (from [[Classical Nahuatl language|Classical Nahuatl]] ''[[wiktionary:calpolli|calpōlli]]'', {{IPA-nah|kaɬˈpoːlːi}}, meaning "large house") was the designation of an organizational unit below the level of the [[altepetl]] "city-state". A Nahua city-state was divided into a number of calpullis, whose inhabitants were collectively responsible for different organizational and religious tasks in relation to the larger altepetl. Calpullis controlled land which was available for calpulli members to cultivate and also operated the [[Tēlpochcalli]] schools for young men of commoner descent. In Aztec culture, as in most other civilizations, the family unit was very important. There were several levels of organization in Aztec family life beginning with the base family unit. The base family unit consisted of two parents and their unmarried children. The main functions of the base family unit were education of the children and food preparation. Many base family units, however, banded together to form extended families. The households of extended families were usually composed of several brothers and their families. The primary functions of the extended families were to coordinate land use and food production (such as growing crops). In most cases, extended families contained just a few base family units. In large cities, however, they often grew to many more.
Although extended families farmed the land, they usually did not own it. They were allowed to use it by the calpulli to which they belonged. Calpulli were groups of families that controlled the use of the land and performed other territorial functions, as well as social ones. The majority of calpulli had a telpuchcalli, a school for young men. Another function of the calpulli was a taxation unit. The empire collected taxes from each calpulli, which in turn collected taxes from its member families.
Most rural calpulli were based on lineage. In other words, the members of a rural calpulli believed that they were descended from a common ancestor. In the cities, the calpulli were based more on geographical, political, and occupational similarities than lineage. In both cases, calpulli were tightly knit and sometimes were even somewhat isolated from other calpulli, both politically and physically. The nature of the interrelatedness between the members of the calpulli is a matter of debate. Traditionally it has been argued that the calpulli was firstly a family unit in which the inhabitants were related through blood and intermarriage. Other scholars such as Van Zantwijk (1985) deny that this was necessarily the case. Van Zantwijk demonstrates that at least in some altepetl the family-based nature of the calpulli was replaced with a hierarchical structure based on wealth and prestige. Newcomers from other altepetl were allowed to settle down and become part of the calpulli. Michael Smith (2003) shows that in some Nahua cities, notably Otumba, each calpulli specialised in a trade and took almost the form of a trade guild.
==Calpullis of Tenochtitlan==
The wards of [[Tenochtitlan]], the Aztec capital, were also known as ''calpulli''. The exact number of calpullis within the city is not known but Van Zantwijk (1985) based his calculations on a wide array of ethnohistorical sources. Van Zantwijk reached a number of 20 calpullis, 7 of which represented the original founding groups of Tenochtitlan and the remaining 13 being composed by groups coming to the city at later points in its development. Van Zantwijk assumed that each calpulli was ritually connected to one of the twenty day names. Below is a list of the twenty calpullis of Tenochtitlan based on the data from Van Zantwijk (1985):
'''Founding calpullis''' *Tlacatecpan *Tlacochcalco *Huitznahuac *Yopico *Chalman *Izquitlan *Cihuatecpan
'''New calpullis''' *Chililico *Coatlan *Apanteuctlan *Acatliacapan *Tzonmolco *Tezcacoac *Tlamatzinco *Molonco Itlillan *Tecpantzinco *Xochicalco *Coatlxoxouhcan *Cuauhquiahuac *Atempan

{{About|the Berber dialect of Central Morocco called Tamazight exclusively|other uses of the word "Tamazight"|Berber language}} {{Infobox language |name=Central Atlas Tamazight |altname=''Tamaziɣt'' |nativename=ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ |pronunciation={{IPA-tam|tæmæˈzɪɣt], [θæmæˈzɪɣθ|}} |states=Morocco |region=[[Middle Atlas]] |speakers=4,590,000 |date=2016 |ref=<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/tzm|title=Tamazight, Central Atlas|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-06-01|language=en}}</ref> |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Berber languages|Berber]] |fam3=[[Northern Berber languages|Northern Berber]] |fam4=[[Atlas languages|Atlas]] |stand1=[[Standard Moroccan Tamazight]] |script=[[Tifinagh]], [[Latin script|Latin]], [[Arabic script|Arabic]] |agency=[[Royal Institute of the Amazigh Culture|IRCAM]] |iso3=tzm |image= |map=Central Atlas Tamazight - EN.PNG |mapcaption={{legend|#F00000|Location of Central Atlas Tamazight speakers}}<small>Central Atlas Tamazight speakers are mostly distributed in a large, contiguous area in central Morocco. |notice=IPA |glotto=cent2194 |glottorefname=Central Atlas Tamazight }} {{Contains Tifinagh text}} '''Central Atlas Tamazight''' (also known as Central Morocco Tamazight, Middle Atlas Tamazight, Tamazight, Central Shilha and, rarely, Beraber or Braber; native name: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ ''Tamazight'' {{IPA-tam|tæmæˈzɪɣt], [θæmæˈzɪɣθ|}}) is a [[Berber language]]<ref group="nb">Central Atlas Tamazight may be referred to as either a Berber language or a Berber dialect. As Berber languages have a some degree of mutual intelligibility, there is little consensus on what is considered a "[[language]]" and what a "[[dialect]]". Additionally, Berber activists like to consider all Berber dialects to be a language to emphasize unity, though this is not entirely linguistically sound (e.g. geographically non-proximate "dialects" may be mutually unintelligible), see {{Harvcoltxt|Brenzinger|2007|p=124}}</ref> of the [[Afroasiatic language family]] spoken by 3 to 5 million people in the [[Atlas Mountains]] of Central [[Morocco]] as well as by smaller emigrant communities in [[France]] and elsewhere.<ref name="eth" /><ref name="inalco" />
Central Atlas Tamazight is one of the most-spoken Berber languages, along with [[Kabyle language|Kabyle]], [[Shilha language|Shilha]], [[Riffian language|Riff]], [[Shawiya language|Shawiya]] and [[Tuareg languages|Tuareg]]. In Morocco, it rivals Shilha as the most-spoken. All five languages may be referred to as "Tamazight", but Central Atlas speakers are the only ones who use the term exclusively. As is typical of Afroasiatic languages, Tamazight has a series of "[[emphatic consonant]]s" (realized as [[pharyngealized]]), [[uvulars]], [[pharyngeals]] and lacks the phoneme /[[Voiceless bilabial plosive|p]]/. Tamazight has a phonemic three-vowel system but also has numerous words without vowels.
Central Atlas Tamazight (unlike neighbouring [[Tashelhit]]) had no known significant writing tradition until the 20th century. It is now officially written in the [[Tifinagh]] script for instruction in Moroccan schools,<ref name="omniglot">{{cite web | title = Tifinagh alphabet and Berber languages | work = Omniglot | publisher = S. Ager | date = n.d. | url = http://www.omniglot.com/writing/tifinagh.htm | accessdate = December 17, 2009}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceC" /> while descriptive linguistic literature commonly uses the [[Latin alphabet]], and the [[Arabic alphabet]] has also been used.
The standard word order is [[verb–subject–object]] but sometimes [[subject–verb–object]].<ref name="am295" /> Words [[Inflection|inflect]] for gender, number and state, using prefixes, suffixes and [[circumfix]]es. [[Verb]]s are heavily inflected, being marked for [[grammatical tense|tense]], [[aspect (grammar)|aspect]], [[grammatical mode|mode]], [[voice (grammar)|voice]], [[grammatical person|person]] of the [[Subject (grammar)|subject]] and [[grammatical polarity|polarity]], sometimes undergoing [[ablaut]]. Pervasive borrowing from [[Arabic]] extends to all major word classes, including verbs; borrowed verbs, however, are conjugated according to native patterns, including [[ablaut]].<ref name="sadiqi25-26" /><ref name="am153" />
== Classification == Central Atlas Tamazight is one of the four most-spoken Berber languages, in addition to [[Kabyle language|Kabyle]], [[Shilha language|Shilha]], and [[Riffian language|Riff]],<ref name="looklex/berber_l" /><ref name="EA5-6" /> and rivals Shilha as the most-spoken Berber language in Morocco.<ref name="ethrep" /><ref name="ross20" /><ref name="ciemen14" /> Differentiating these dialects is complicated by the fact that speakers of other languages may also refer to their language as 'Tamazight'.<ref name="inalco" /> The differences between all three groups are largely [[phonology|phonological]] and [[lexicon|lexical]], rather than [[syntax|syntactic]].<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=2" /> Tamazight itself has a relatively large degree of internal diversity, including whether [[spirantization]] occurs.<ref name="inalco" /><ref name="stroomer1">{{Harvcoltxt|Kossmann|Stroomer|1997|p=461}}</ref>
Central Atlas Tamazight speakers refer to themselves as ''Amazigh'' (pl. ''Imazighen''), an [[endonym]]ic [[ethnonym]] whose etymology is uncertain, but may translate as "free people".<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Brenzinger|2007|p=124}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = The Etymology of the Word "Amazigh" | last = Messaoudi | first = D. | year = 2009 | publisher = Scribd | accessdate = March 21, 2010 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/15056143/The-Etymology-of-the-Word-Amazigh}}</ref> The term ''Tamazight'', the feminine form of ''Amazigh'', refers to the language. Both words are also used self-referentially by other Berber groups to replace local terms such as [[Chleuh|ašəlḥi]] or [[Riffian people|rifi]], although Central Atlas Tamazight speakers use them regularly and exclusively.<ref name="inalco">{{harvnb|Chaker}}</ref><ref group="nb">Using {{angle bracket|gh}} for {{IPA|[ɣ]}} when embedding Berber words in English text follows the tradition set by French-language publications, even those written by Berbers {{Harvcoltxt|Goodman|2005|p=xii}}. The name "Tamazirt" results from French transcription of Tamazight {{IPA|/ɣ/}} with the letter {{angle bracket|r}}, which in French represents the similar-sounding phoneme {{IPA|/ʁ/}}. Cf. {{Harvcoltxt|Souag|2004}}</ref>
In older studies, Central Atlas Tamazight is sometimes referred to as "Braber" / "Beraber", a dialetical Arabic term, or its Tamazight equivalent "Taberbrit".<ref name="inalco" /><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=1}}</ref> This is related to the Standard Arabic and English term "Berber", used to refer to all Berber dialects/languages, though eschewed by many Berbers because its etymology is pejorative.<ref name="multi" />
Tamazight belongs to the [[Berber languages|Berber]] branch of the [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic]] language family; Afroasiatic subsumes a number of languages in [[North Africa]] and [[Southwest Asia]] including the [[Semitic languages]], the [[Egyptian language]], and the [[Chadic languages|Chadic]] and [[Cushitic languages]]. Along with most other Berber languages, Tamazight has retained a number of widespread Afroasiatic features, including a two-[[grammatical gender|gender]] system, [[verb–subject–object]] (VSO) [[linguistic typology|typology]], emphatic consonants (realized in Tamazight as pharyngealized), a [[templatic morphology]], and a [[causative]] morpheme /s/ (the latter also found in other macrofamilies, such as the [[Niger–Congo languages]].) Within Berber, Central Atlas Tamazight belongs, along with neighbouring [[Tashelhiyt]], to the [[Atlas languages|Atlas]] branch of the [[Northern Berber languages|Northern Berber]] subgroup.
Tamazight is in the middle of a [[dialect continuum]] between Riff to its north-east and Shilha to its south-west.<ref name="inalco" /> The basic lexicon of Tamazight differs markedly from Shilha, and its verbal system is more similar to Riff or Kabyle.<ref name="inalco" /> Moreover, Tamazight has a greater amount of internal diversity than Shilha.<ref name="stroomer1"/>
Tamazight's dialects are divided into three distinct subgroups and geographic regions: those spoken in the [[Middle Atlas]] mountains; those spoken in the [[High Atlas]] mountains; and those spoken in [[Jbel Saghro]] and its foothills.<ref name="inalco" /> Although the characteristic spirantization of {{IPA|/b/}} > {{IPA|[β]}}; {{IPA|/t/}} > {{IPA|[θ]}} or {{IPA|[h]}}; {{IPA|/d/}} > {{IPA|[ð]}}; {{IPA|/k/}} > {{IPA|[ç]}} or {{IPA|[ʃ]}}; and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} > {{IPA|[ʝ]}}, {{IPA|[ʃ]}} or {{IPA|[j]}} is apparent in Berber languages in central and northern Morocco and Algeria,<ref>{{cite web |title=The Tamazight Language Profile |last=Achab |first=Karim |publisher=University of Ottawa |year=2001 |url=http://acaoh.ca/?p=38 |at=III.9 Dialectic variation |accessdate=December 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207231714/http://acaoh.ca/?p=38 |archivedate=February 7, 2009 |df= }}</ref> as in many Middle Atlas dialects, it is more rare in High Atlas Tamazight speakers, and is absent in Tamazight speakers from the foothills of [[Jbel Saghro]].<ref name="inalco" /><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=5}}</ref> Southern dialects (e.g. [[Ayt Atta]]) may also be differentiated syntactically: while other dialects predicate with the auxiliary /d/ (e.g. /d argaz/ "it's a man"), Southern dialects use the typically (High Atlas, Souss-Basin rural country, Jbel Atlas Saghro) auxiliary verb /g/ (e.g. /iga argaz/ "it's a man").<ref name="inalco" /> The differences between each of the three groups are primarily phonological.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=2" />
Groups speaking Tamazight include: Ait Ayache, Ait Morghi, Ait Alaham, Ait Youb, Marmoucha, Ait Youssi, Beni Mguild, [[Zayanes|Zayane]], Zemmour, Ait Rbaa, Ait Seri, Guerouane, Ait Segougou, [[Ait Yafelman]], Ait Sikhmane, Ayt Ndhir (Beni Mtir).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971a|p=ix}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=4}}</ref><ref group="nb">({{IPA|/ajt~/}} literally means "children of ~", see {{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=118}}</ref>
There is some ambiguity as to the eastern boundary of Central Atlas Tamazight. The dialect of the [[Ait Seghrouchen Berber|Ait Seghrouchen]] and [[Ait Ouarain]] tribes are commonly classed as Central Atlas Tamazight, and Ait Seghrouchen is reported to be mutually intelligible with the neighbouring Tamazight dialect of Ait Ayache.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=xiii}}</ref> Genetically, however, they belong to the [[Zenati languages|Zenati]] subgroup of Northern Berber, rather than to the Atlas subgroup to which the rest of Central Atlas Tamazight belongs,<ref>[[Edmond Destaing]], "Essai de classification des dialectes berbères du Maroc", ''Études et Documents Berbère'', 19-20, 2001-2002 (1915)</ref> and are therefore excluded by some sources from Central Atlas Tamazight.<ref>Augustin Bernard and Paul Moussard, Arabophones et berbérophones au Maroc, ''[[Annales de Géographie]]'' 1924, Volume 33 Numéro 183, pp. 267-282.</ref> The [[Ethnologue]] lists another group of Zenati dialects, [[South Oran Berber]] (''ksours sud-oranais''), as a dialect of Central Atlas Tamazight,<ref name="eth">{{cite web | title = Tamazight, Central Atlas | publisher = [[SIL International]] | date = n.d. | url = http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=tzm | accessdate = December 17, 2009}}</ref> but these are even less similar, and are treated by Berber specialists as a separate dialect group.<ref>Maarten Kossmann, "Grammatical notes on the Berber dialect of Igli (Sud oranais, Algeria)", in ed. D. Ibriszimow, M. Kossmann, H. Stroomer, R. Vossen, Études berbères V – Essais sur des variations dialectales et autres articles. Köln: Rüdiger Köppe, 2010.</ref><!-- the map in this article currently reflects the Ethnologue position-->
== History == {{See also|Berber people|History of Morocco}}
The Berbers have lived in North Africa between western Egypt and the Atlantic Ocean since before recorded history began in the region about 33 centuries ago.<ref name="legal">{{cite conference |last=Balkassm |first=Hasan |year=2008 |title=Legal and constitutional status of Amazigh language in Morocco & North Africa |conference=International Expert Group Meeting on Indigenous Languages (UNPFII) |conferenceurl=https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/en/EGM_IL.html |url=https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/EGM_IL_Balkassm_en.ppt |accessdate=December 20, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="The Berbers - History">{{cite web | title = The Berbers – History | publisher = Arabic German Consulting | date = n.d. | url = http://www.arab.de/arabinfo/berbers.htm | accessdate = December 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=2">{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=2}}</ref> By the 5th century BC, the city of [[Carthage]], founded by [[Phoenicia]]ns, had extended its hegemony across much of [[North Africa]]; in the wake of the [[Punic Wars]], [[Rome]] replaced it as regional hegemon. The Central Atlas region itself remained independent throughout the classical period, but occasional loanwords into Central Atlas Tamazight, such as ''ayugu'', "plough ox", from [[Latin]] ''iugum'', "team of oxen"<ref>Vermondo Brugnatelli, "I prestiti latini in berbero: un bilancio", 9° Incontro di Linguistica Afroasiatica (Camito-Semitica), Trieste, 23-24 aprile 1998, http://www.brugnatelli.net/vermondo/articoli/Trieste.html</ref> and ''aẓalim'' "onion" < [[Punic language|Punic]] ''bṣal-im'',<ref>Abdel-Massih 1971; Werner Vycichl, ''Berberstudien & A Sketch of Siwi Berber (Egypt)''. Ed. Dymitr Ibriszimow & Maarten Kossmann. Berber Studies, vol. 10. Cologne: Rüdiger Köppe Verlag. {{ISBN|3-89645-389-0}}</ref> bear witness to their ancestors' contact with these conquerors.
Arabs conquered the area of modern-day [[Morocco]] and [[Algeria]] around the 7th century,<ref name="the_berbers">{{cite web |title=The Berbers |publisher=B. Whitaker |year=2009 |url=http://www.al-bab.com/arab/background/berber.htm |accessdate=December 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819165403/http://al-bab.com/arab/background/berber.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2013 |df= }}</ref> prompting waves of Arab migration and Berber adoption of [[Islam]].<ref name="wdm">{{cite web | title = Berbers | work = World Directory of Minorities | publisher = [[Gale (publisher)|The Gale Group]] | date = n.d. | url = http://www.faqs.org/minorities/Middle-East-and-North-Africa/Berbers.html | accessdate = December 17, 2009}}</ref> Particularly following the arrival of the [[Banu Hilal]] in modern-day [[Tunisia]] in the 11th century, more and more of North Africa became Arabic-speaking over the centuries. However, along with other high mountainous regions of North Africa, the Middle Atlas continued to speak Berber.
[[File:Almoravids1120.png|thumb|200px|alt=Map of the Almoravid dynasty in green at its greatest extent, circa 1120. The territory covered most of the Northern reaches of Northern Africa, as well as Southern Iberia.|The Almoravid dynasty (green) at its greatest extent, c. 1120.]]
Between the 12th and 15th centuries, the Central Atlas, along with the rest of Morocco, successively fell within the domain of the Berber [[Almoravid dynasty|Almoravid]], [[Almohad Caliphate|Almohad]], and [[Marinid dynasty|Marinid]] dynasties. Since the 17th century the region has acknowledged the rule of the [[Alaouite Dynasty]], the current Moroccan royal family. However, effective control of the region was limited; until the 20th century much of the Central Atlas was in a condition of ''siba'', recognising the spiritual legitimacy of royal authority but rejecting its political claims.<ref>David Hart, ''Qabila: tribal profiles and tribe-state relations in Morocco and on the Afghanistan-Pakistan frontier'', 2001, p. 33</ref> The expansion of the [[Ait Atta]] starting from the 16th century brought Tamazight back into the already Arabised [[Tafilalt]] region<ref>{{cite book|first=Larbi |last=Mezzine |title=Le Tafilalt, Contribution à l'histoire du Maroc aux XVIIè et XVIIIè siècles | journal=Publications de la FLSH, [[Mohammed V University]] |location= Rabat |year= 1987 |language=French}}</ref> and put other regional tribes on the defensive, leading to the formation of the [[Ait Yafelman]] alliance.
The 1912 [[Treaty of Fez]] made most of Morocco a French-Spanish protectorate (under French and Spanish military occupation), leaving the Alaouite monarchy but establishing a French military presence in the Atlas region and installing a French commissioner-general.<ref>{{cite web | title = Jewish Population of French North Africa | last = Sussman | first = Sarah | work = Holocaust Encyclopedia | publisher = United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington | date = n.d. | url = http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/article.php?lang=en&ModuleId=10007310 | accessdate = December 18, 2009}}</ref> However, the Berber tribes of the Middle Atlas, as in other areas, put up stiff military resistance to French rule, lasting until 1933 in the case of the [[Ait Atta]].
After Morocco's independence in 1956, a strong emphasis was laid on the country's [[Arab]] identity,<ref name="textiles">{{Harvcoltxt|Becker|2006}}</ref> and a national [[Arabic language]] educational system was instituted, in which Berber languages, including Middle Atlas Tamazight, had no place. However, in 1994 the government responded to Berber demands for recognition by decreeing that Berber should be taught and establishing television broadcasts in three Berber languages, including Central Atlas Tamazight.<ref>Joël Donnet, APRÈS DEUX MILLE ANS DE MÉPRIS: Renaissance berbère au Maroc, ''Le Monde diplomatique'' Jan. 1995</ref> For the promotion of Tamazight and other Berber languages and cultures, the government created the [[Royal Institute of Amazigh Culture]] (IRCAM) in 2001.<ref name="oblivion">{{cite web |last=El Jechtimi |first=Ahmed |year=2009 |title=Amazigh from oblivion to the classroom |publisher=Agence Maghreb Arabe Presse |location=Rabat |url=http://www.map.ma/eng/sections/culture/amazigh_from_oblivio/view |accessdate=December 20, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="IRCAM_dahir">[[Wikisource:Dahir n° 1-01-299]]</ref>
== Geographic distribution == [[File:Percent of Tamazight speakers in Morocco by census 2004.png|thumb|Percent of Tmazight speakers in Morocco by census 2004 Based on data found [http://www.hcp.ma/Recensement-general-de-la-population-et-de-l-habitat-2004_a633.html Here]]] Central Atlas Tamazight is among the four most-spoken Berber languages (the other three being [[Kabyle language|Kabyle]], [[Shilha language|Shilha]], and [[Riffian language|Riff]]),<ref name="looklex/berber_l">{{cite web | title = Berber | last = Kjeilen | first = Tore | work = LookLex Encyclopedia | publisher = LookLex Ltd. | date = n.d. | url = http://looklex.com/e.o/berber_l.htm | accessdate = December 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="EA5-6">{{Harvcoltxt|El Aissati|1993|pp=5–6}}</ref> and rivals Shilha as the most-spoken Berber language in Morocco.<ref name="ethrep">{{cite web | title = Ethnologue report for Morocco | publisher = [[SIL International]] | date = n.d. | url = http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=MA | accessdate = December 18, 2009}}</ref><ref name="ross20">{{Harvcoltxt|Ross|2004|p=20}}</ref><ref name="ciemen14">{{harvnb|Moustaoui|loc = 1.3 The distribution of speakers in the territory}}</ref> Central Atlas Tamazight is mostly spoken in the entire Middle Atlas and its outcroppings, reaching east to [[Taza]] and west to the region near [[Rabat]].<ref name="eth" /><ref name="inalco" /><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=2}}</ref> It is also spoken in the central and eastern High Atlas mountains in Morocco.<ref name="inalco" /> It is thus spoken across areas with widely varying ecological conditions — from the mountainous and forested regions of the Middle Atlas mountains to the oases of the northwestern Sahara (''[[Tafilalt]]'').<ref name="inalco" /> Berber in Morocco is spread into three areas: Riff in the north, Central Atlas in the center, and Shilha in the south/southwest.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Chaker|2003|p=2}}</ref> Central Atlas is not mutually intelligible with the Riff language but is with the Shilha dialect; Shilha- and Riff-speakers also cannot understand each other,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Brenzinger|2007|p=125}}</ref> That said, the Riffian language is of course related to both Shilha and Atlas Tamazight, and even though Riffian and the other two are not mutually intelligible, they share a high degree of the same vocabulary and grammar.<ref name="inalco" />
Figures for the number of speakers of Berber languages are generally a matter of estimates rather than linguistic censuses.<ref name="EA5-6" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Berber Language Page |publisher=African Studies Center |location=Michigan |date=n.d. |at=2 Number of Speakers |url=http://isp.msu.edu/AfrLang/Handbook/Berber_root.htm |accessdate=December 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515135709/http://isp.msu.edu/AfrLang/Handbook/Berber_root.htm |archivedate=May 15, 2008 }}</ref> At least a third of Moroccans seem to speak Berber languages,.<ref group="nb">André Basset estimated in 1952 that a "small majority" of Morocco's population spoke Berber, see {{citation | last = Basset | first = André | year = 1952 | title = La langue berbère | work = Handbook of African Languages, Part I | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = London }}</ref><ref>The 1960 census estimated via interpolation that 37% of Moroccans were Berbers, see {{cite web | title = Berbers of Morocco – Orientation | publisher = everyculture.org | url = http://www.everyculture.com/Africa-Middle-East/Berbers-of-Morocco-Orientation.html | accessdate = December 19, 2009}}</ref><ref name="ethnote" group="nb">According to the Ethnologue (by deduction from its Moroccan Arabic figures), the Berber-speaking population should be estimated at 35% or around 10.5 million speakers. However, the figures provided for individual languages only add up to 7.5 million, divided into the three dialects as follows: Riff at 1.5 million speakers in 1991; Shilha at 3 million speakers in 1998; and Central Atlas Tamazight at 3 million in 1998, which would give Central Atlas 40%, Shilha 40%, and Riff 20% of the total. See :{{cite web |title=Languages of Morocco |publisher=SIL International |date=n.d. |url=http://www.ethnologue.com/14/show_country.asp?name=Morocco |accessdate=December 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071119004808/http://www.ethnologue.com/14/show_country.asp?name=Morocco |archivedate=November 19, 2007 |df= }} :{{cite web |title=Tarifit |publisher=SIL International |date=n.d. |url=http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=rif |accessdate=December 20, 2009 }} :{{cite web |title=Tachelhit |publisher=SIL International |date=n.d. |url=http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=shi |accessdate=December 20, 2009 }} :{{cite web |title=Tamazight, Central Atlas |publisher=SIL International |url=http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=tzm |date=December 20, 2009 }}</ref> Tamazight is estimated to be spoken by about 40~49% of Morocco's Berber-speakers, while Shilha commands 32~40% and Riff 20~25%.<ref name="ross20" /><ref name="ethnote" group="nb"/>
== Status ==
Tamazight, along with other Berber languages of Morocco, has a low sociolinguistic status, used mainly in the home, and rarely in official or formal contexts. Media broadcasts and music are available in it,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|El Aissati|1993|p=8,10}}</ref> and there is a policy of teaching it in schools.
Of the Central Atlas Tamazight speakers, 40–45% are monolingual, while the others use Arabic as a second language.<ref name="eth" /> Monolingual speakers consist mostly of older generations and children.<ref name="multi">{{Harvcoltxt|Ennaji|2005|p=71}}</ref> Women are more likely to be monolingual than men, since they typically stay in the village while the men go to work in the cities.<ref name="textiles" /> Since Tamazight is the language of the home, girls grow up speaking Berber languages and pass them on to their children — this gender stratification helps to preserve the language.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=3}}</ref> Bilingual Berber speakers have learned [[Moroccan Arabic]] via schooling, migration, media, or through the government.<ref name="multi" /> Most rural Berber children are monolingual. They struggle to succeed in schools where the teachers do not speak Berber, and require them to learn both Arabic and French.<ref name="multi" />
Rural Morocco, including the Central Atlas area, suffers from poverty. Tamazight along with its relative Shilha are undergoing "contraction" as rural families, motivated by economic necessity,<ref name="wdm" /> move to cities and stop speaking Tamazight, leading many intellectuals to fear Berber language shift or regression.<ref name="multi" /><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Hoffman|2006|p=148}}</ref> However, Tamazight speakers are reported to immigrate less than many other Berber groups.<ref name="ea7">{{Harvcoltxt|El Aissati|1993|p=7}}</ref> Moreover, Tamazight has a large enough body of native speakers not to be considered under risk of endangerment,<ref name="ReferenceC">{{Harvcoltxt|Brenzinger|2007|p=128}}</ref> although Tamazight speakers reportedly have a lower birth rate than the country of Morocco as a whole.<ref name="ea7" />
=== Official status === [[File:IRCAM-Rabat.jpg|thumb|300px|alt=The entrance to the IRCAM (Institut Royal de la Culture Amazighe) building in Rabat. Two women are standing in front of a large, metal plaque with the word "IRCAM" written on it in large letters, and the organization's logo.|The [[Institut Royal de la Culture Amazighe|IRCAM]] (Institut Royal de la Culture Amazighe) in [[Rabat]]]] {{main|Standard Moroccan Tamazight}} As of the [[Moroccan constitutional referendum, 2011]], the Berber languages are official in Morocco alongside Arabic. In 1994, [[King Hassan II]] declared that a national Berber dialect would acquire a formal status; television broadcasts are summarized in Tamazight, as well as Shilha and Rif, three times a day; and educational materials for schools are being developed.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Harvcoltxt|van Heelsum|2002|p=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Berber Language Page |publisher=African Studies Center |location=Michigan |date=n.d. |at=3 Dialect Survey |url=http://isp.msu.edu/AfrLang/Handbook/Berber_root.htm |accessdate=December 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515135709/http://isp.msu.edu/AfrLang/Handbook/Berber_root.htm |archivedate=May 15, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="revival">{{cite web | last = Benmhend | first = Driss | title = The Amazigh Revival in Morocco | publisher = Gourad Media Group LLC. | location = Georgetown | year = 1997 | url = http://www.wafin.com/driss.phtml | accessdate = December 18, 2009 }}</ref> On October 17, 2001 King Mohammed VI sealed the decree ([[Moroccan Dahir|Dahir]] 1–01–299) creating and organizing the [[Royal Institute of Amazigh Culture]] (IRCAM).<ref name="oblivion" /><ref name="IRCAM_dahir" /> IRCAM's board is composed of Amazigh experts, artists, and activists, all of whom are appointed by the king.<ref name="choice">{{cite journal | last = Larbi | first = Hsen | title = Which Script for Tamazight, Whose Choice is it ? | journal = Amazigh Voice (Taghect Tamazight) | volume = 12 | issue = 2 | year = 2003 | publisher = Amazigh Cultural Association in America (ACAA) | location = New Jersey | url = http://www.tamazgha.fr/Which-Script-for-Tamazight-Whose-Choice-is-it,359.html | accessdate = December 17, 2009 }}</ref> The institute, located in [[Rabat]], has played an important role in the establishment of the [[Tifinagh]] script in Morocco.<ref name="choice" /> There are multiple political parties and cultural associations in Morocco that advocate for the advancement of Berber, calling for it to be recognized as an official language, used more extensively in the mass media, and taught more in schools.<ref name="legal" /><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|El Aissati|1993|pp=11–12}}</ref>
A legal issue affecting Tamazight speakers is restrictions on naming - Moroccan law stipulates that first names must have a "Moroccan character", and uncommon names, including some Berber ones used in the Central Atlas, are often rejected by the civil registry.<ref name="ReferenceA" /><ref name="names">{{cite web | title = Morocco: Lift Restrictions on Amazigh (Berber) Names | publisher = Human Rights Watch | location = New York | date = September 3, 2009 | url = https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/09/03/morocco-lift-restrictions-amazigh-berber-names | accessdate = December 18, 2009 }}</ref>
== Orthography == {{Main|Berber orthography}}
[[File:Central Morocco Tamazight in Tifinagh.svg|thumb|150px|alt=The word ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ.|''Tamaziɣt'' in [[Tifinagh]]]] Until the 20th century Tamazight, like many other Berber languages but in contrast with neighbouring [[Tashelhiyt]], was basically unwritten<ref name="amviii">{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971a|p=viii}}</ref><ref name="sec14">{{Harvcoltxt|Ben-Layashi|2007|p=166}}</ref> (although sporadic cases, using Arabic script, are attested.<ref>Ahmed Touderti, Une prophétie berbère en tamazight (Maroc central), ''Etudes et Documents Berbères'', 15-16, 1998 : pp. 101-113</ref>) It was preserved through oral use in rural areas, isolated from urban hubs.<ref name="sec14" /> Scholars from the Middle Atlas, as elsewhere in North Africa, usually wrote in the more prestigious Arabic language, rather than their vernacular.<ref name="sec14" />
At present three writing systems exist for Berber languages, including Tamazight: [[Neo-Tifinagh]], the [[Latin alphabet]] and the [[Arabic script]].<ref name="choice" /> To some extent, the choice of writing system is a political one, with various subgroups expressing preference based on ideology and politics.<ref name="choice" /> The orthography used for government services including schooling is Neo-Tifinagh, rendered official by a [[Moroccan Dahir|Dahir]] of King Mohammed VI based on the recommendation of IRCAM.<ref name="choice" /> However, various Latin transcriptions have been used in a number of linguistic works describing Central Atlas Tamazight, notably the dictionary of Taïfi (1991).<ref>Miloud Taïfi, Dictionnaire tamazight-français (parlers du Maroc central), Paris, L'Harmattan-Awal, 1991</ref>
== Phonology ==
=== Consonants === Central Atlas Tamazight has a contrastive set of "flat" consonants, manifested in two ways:
* For front segments, [[pharyngealization]]: {{IPA|/tˤ dˤ sˤ zˤ lˤ nˤ rˤ/}}) * For back segments, [[labialization]]: {{IPA|/xʷ ɣʷ qʷ χʷ ʁʷ/}})
Note that pharyngealization may spread to a syllable or even a whole word.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=7">{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=7}}</ref> Historically [[Proto-Berber language|Proto-Berber]] only had two pharyngealized phonemes ({{IPA|/dˤ, zˤ/}}), but modern Berber languages have borrowed others from Arabic and developed new ones through sound shifts.<ref name="ks464">{{Harvcoltxt|Kossman|Stroomer|1997|p=464}}</ref>
In addition Tamazight has uvular and pharyngeal consonants, as well as a conspicuous lack of {{IPA|/p/}} in its plosive inventory.<ref group="nb">{{IPA|[p]}} is missing from about 10% of languages that have a {{IPA|[b]}}. (See [[voiced velar plosive]] for another such gap.) This is an [[areal feature (linguistics)|areal feature]] of the "circum-Saharan zone" (Africa north of the equator plus the [[Arabian peninsula]]). It is not known how old this areal feature is, and whether it might be a recent phenomenon due to Arabic as a prestige language (Arabic lost its {{IPA|/p/}} in prehistoric times), or whether Arabic was itself affected by a more ancient areal pattern. It is found in other areas as well; for example, in Europe, [[Proto-Celtic language|Proto-Celtic]] is reconstructed as having {{IPA|[b]}} but no {{IPA|[p]}}. Nonetheless, the {{IPA|[p]}} sound is very common cross-linguistically.</ref>
All segments may be [[geminate consonant|geminated]] except for the pharyngeals {{IPA|/ʕ ħ/}}. In Ayt Ndhir, which is a dialect of Tamazight with spirantization, the spirantizeable consonants appear in their stop forms when geminated, and additionally the geminate correspondents of {{IPA|/ʁ, dˤ, ʃ, ʒ, w, j/}} are usually {{IPA|/qː, tˤː, t͡ʃː, d͡ʒː, ɣʷː, ɣː/}} respectively. However some native Berber words have {{IPA|/ʁː/}} (not {{IPA|/qː/}}) where other dialects have singleton {{IPA|/ʁ/}}, and similarly for {{IPA|/ʃː, ʒː/}}.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|pp=5–7}}</ref> In addition, in Arabic loans singleton non-spirantized {{IPA|[b, t, tˤ, d, k, ɡ, q]}} occur (though {{IPA|[b t d]}} and to an extent {{IPA|[tˤ]}} often alternate with their spirantized versions in loans), giving this alternation marginal phonemic status.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=7" />
In the table below, when consonants appear in pairs, the one on the left is voiceless.

Tamazight has a typical phonemic [[Vowel#Use of vowels in languages|three-vowel system]]:

'''Phonetic Schwa'''
There is a predictable non-phonemic vowel inserted into consonant clusters, realized as {{IPAblink|ɪ̈}} before front consonants (e.g. {{IPA|/b t d .../}}) and {{IPAblink|ə}} before back consonants (e.g. {{IPA|/k χ .../)}}.<ref name="am15">{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=15}}</ref> It is voiced before voiced consonants and voiceless before voiceless consonants, or alternatively it can be realized as a voiced or unvoiced consonant release.<ref name="am15" /><ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10">{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10}}</ref> It also may be realized as the syllabicity of a nasal, lateral, or /r/.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10" />
The occurrence of schwa [[epenthesis]] is governed morphophonemically.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10">{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10}}</ref> These are some of the rules governing the occurrence of {{IPA|[ə]}}:
(# denotes word boundary, L denotes {{IPA|/l r m n/}}, H denotes {{IPA|/h ħ ʕ w j/}})
{| class="wikitable" |+ Tamazight schwa epenthesis<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=15–17}}</ref> |- ! Environment ! Realization ! Example ! Pronunciation ! Gloss |- ! #C(ː)# | əC(ː) | {{IPA|/ɡ/}} | {{IPA|[əɡ]}} | 'to be, to do' |- !#LC# | əLC or LəC | {{IPA|/ns/}} | {{IPA|[əns] ~ [nəs]}} | 'to spend the night' |- !#CC# | CəC | {{IPA|/tˤsˤ/}} | {{IPA|[tˤəsˤ]}} | 'to laugh' |- ! #CːC# | əCːəC | {{IPA|/fːr/}} | {{IPA|[əfːər]}} | 'to hide' |- ! rowspan="2" | #CCC# | rowspan="2" | CCəC / C1C2 are not {L H} | {{IPA|/χdm/}} | {{IPA|[χdəm]}} | 'to work' |- | {{IPA|/zʕf/}} | {{IPA|[zʕəf]}} | 'to get mad' |- ! #CCC# | əCCəC or #CəCəC# / {C1 C3} is {L H} | {{IPA|/hdm/}} | {{IPA|[əhdəm] ~ [hədəm]}} | 'to demolish' |- ! #CCC# | CəCəC / C2C3 = {L H} | {{IPA|/dˤmn/}} | {{IPA|[dˤəmən]}} | 'to guarantee' |}
Examples: *{{IPA|/tbrˤːmnt/}} > {{IPA|[tbərːəmənt]}} ('you (fp) turned') *{{IPA|/datːħadˤar/}} > {{IPA|[datːəħadˤar]}} ('she is present') *{{IPA|/ʕadˤːrˤ/}} > {{IPA|[ʕadˤːərˤ]}} ('to meet')
However note that word-initial initial {{IPA|/j, w/}} are realized as {{IPA|/i, u/}} before consonants. In word-medial or -final position {{IPA|[əj]}}, {{IPA|[əʝ]}}, and {{IPA|[əw]}} are realized as {{IPA|[ij]}}, {{IPA|[ij]}}, and {{IPA|[uw]}} respectively, and may become {{IPA|[i]}} and {{IPA|[u]}} in rapid speech.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=10" />
Tamazight in fact has numerous [[words without vowels|words without phonemic vowels]], and those consisting entirely of voiceless consonants will not phonetically contain voiced vowels.<ref group="nb">Audio recordings of selected words without vowels in [[Shilha language|Shilha]] can be downloaded from {{cite web|url=http://ed268.univ-paris3.fr/lpp/pages/EQUIPE/ridouane/audio.doc |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320021843/http://ed268.univ-paris3.fr/lpp/pages/EQUIPE/ridouane/audio.doc |archivedate=2009-03-20 |df= }}.</ref>
{{IPA|[ə]}} is written as {{angle bracket|ⴻ}} in [[neo-Tifinagh]] and as {{angle bracket|e}} in the [[Berber Latin alphabet]]. French publications tended to include {{IPA|[ə]}} in their transcriptions of Berber forms despite their predictability, perhaps due to the [[French phonology|French vowel system]]. This can cause problems because alternations such as {{IPA|/iʁ(ə)rs/}} 'he slaughtered' – {{IPA|/uriʁris/}} 'he did not slaughter' would then have to conditioned morphologically.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1968|pp=3–4}}</ref>
=== Stress ===
[[Stress (linguistics)|Word stress]] is non-contrastive and predictable — it falls on the last vowel in a word (including schwa).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=17–18}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=11}}</ref>
Examples: *{{IPA|/sal/}} > {{IPA|[ˈsal]}} ('to ask') *{{IPA|/dajtːħadˤarˤ/}} > {{IPA|[dajtːəħaˈdˤarˤ]}} ('he is present') *{{IPA|/fsːr/}} > {{IPA|[fəsːˈər]}} ('to explain') *{{IPA|/tfsːrnt/}} > {{IPA|[təfəsːəˈrənt]}} ('you (fp) explained')
== Grammar == {{Main|Central Atlas Tamazight grammar}}
Central Atlas Tamazight grammar has many features typical of [[Afro-Asiatic languages]], including extensive [[apophony]] in both the derivational and inflectional morphology, [[grammatical gender|gender]], [[possessive suffix]]es, [[verb–subject–object|VSO]] typology, the causative morpheme /s/, and use of the [[status constructus]].
=== Morphology ===
Tamazight [[noun]]s are inflected for gender, number, and state. Singular masculine nouns usually have the prefix /a-/, and singular feminines the [[circumfix]] {{IPA|/t...t}}.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=88–89}}</ref> Plurals may either involve a regular change ("sound plurals"), internal vowel change ("broken plurals"), or a combination of the two.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=97}}</ref> Masculine plurals usually take the prefix {{IPA|/i-/}}, feminines {{IPA|/ti-/}}, and sound plurals also take the suffix {{IPA|/-n/}} in masculine and {{IPA|/-in/}}} in feminine, although many other plural patterns are found too.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=88–89, 93–96}}</ref>
Examples:<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=97–112}}</ref> : {{IPA|/'''a'''xam/ → /'''i'''xam'''n'''/}} 'big tent(s)' (m) : {{IPA|/'''a'''maziɣ/ → /'''i'''maziɣ'''n'''/}} 'Berber(s)' (m) : {{IPA|/'''a'''daʃu/ → /'''i'''d'''u'''ʃ'''a'''/}} 'sandal(s)' (m) : {{IPA|/'''a'''srdun/ → /'''i'''srd'''a'''n/}} 'mule(s)' (m) : {{IPA|/'''ta'''xam'''t'''/ → /'''ti'''xam'''in'''/}} 'tent(s)' (f) : {{IPA|/'''ta'''funas'''t'''/ → /'''ti'''funas'''in'''/}} 'cow(s)' (f) : {{IPA|/'''ta'''ɡrtil'''t'''/ → /'''ti'''ɡrt'''a'''l/}} 'mat(s)' (f) : {{IPA|/'''ta'''mazir'''t'''/ → /'''ti'''m'''i'''z'''a'''r/}} 'property(ies)' (f)
Nouns may be put into the [[construct state]] (contrasting with free state) to indicate possession, or when the subject of a verb follows the verb. This is also used for nouns following numerals and some prepositions, as well as the conjunction {{IPA|/d-/}} ('and').<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=121–123}}</ref> The construct state is formed as follows: in masculines, initial {{IPA|/a/}} becomes {{IPA|/u, wː, wa/}}, initial {{IPA|/i/}} becomes {{IPA|/i, j, ji/}}, and initial {{IPA|/u/}} becomes {{IPA|/wu/}}. In feminines, initial {{IPA|/ta/}} usually becomes {{IPA|/t/}}, initial {{IPA|/ti/}} usually becomes {{IPA|/t/}}, and initial {{IPA|/tu/}} remains unchanged.<ref name="am119-121">{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=119–121}}</ref>
Examples (in Ayt Ayache):<ref name="am119-121" /> : {{IPA|/babuxam/}} ( ← {{IPA|/axam/}}) 'head of the house' : {{IPA|/ijːs ntslit/}} ( ← {{IPA|/tislit/}}) 'the horse of the bride'
Central Atlas Tamazight's personal [[pronoun]]s distinguish three persons, and two genders. Pronouns appear in three forms: an independent form used in the subject position, a [[possessive suffix]] (and a derived independent possessive pronoun), and an object form affixed<ref group="nb">prefixed or suffixed depending on multiple factors</ref> to the controlling verb.
Demonstrative pronouns distinguish between proximate and remote. When they occur independently, they inflect for number. They may also be suffixed to nouns, e.g. /tabardaja/ 'this pack-saddle'.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=69, 81}}</ref>
<div style="float:right; margin-left:20px"> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+ <small>Tamazight subject affixes</small><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=159, 217}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|pp=25–26}}</ref> !colspan="3"| Person !! <small>(Ayt Ayache)</small> !! <small>(Ayt Ndhir)</small> |- ! rowspan="4"| s ! colspan="2"|1 | {{IPA|/...-ɣ/}} ||| {{IPA|/...-x/}} |- ! colspan="2"|2 | {{IPA|/t-...-d/}} || {{IPA|/θ-...-ð/}} |- ! rowspan="2"|3 | <small>m</small> || {{IPA|/i-.../}} || {{IPA|/j-.../}} |- | <small>f</small> || {{IPA|/t-.../}} || {{IPA|/θ-.../}} |- ! rowspan="5"| pl ! colspan="2"|1 |colspan="2"| {{IPA|/n-.../}} |- ! rowspan="2"|2 | <small>m</small> || {{IPA|/t-...-m/}} || {{IPA|/θ-...-m/}} |- | <small>f</small> || {{IPA|/t-...-nt/}} || {{IPA|/θ-...-nθ/}} |- ! rowspan="2"|3 | <small>m</small> |colspan="2"| {{IPA|/...-n/}} |- | <small>f</small> || {{IPA|/...-nt/}} || {{IPA|/...-nθ/}} |} </div>
Central Atlas Tamazight verbs are heavily inflected, being marked for [[grammatical tense|tense]], [[aspect (grammar)|aspect]], [[grammatical mode|mode]], [[voice (grammar)|voice]], [[grammatical person|person]], and [[grammatical polarity|polarity]]. Tamazight verbs have at their core a stem, modified by prefixes, suffixes, moveable affixes, circumfixes, and [[ablaut]]. The prefixes indicate voice, tense, aspect, and polarity, while the suffixes indicate mood (normal, horatory, or imperative). Subject markers are circumfixed to the verb, while object marking and [[satellite framing]] are accomplished via either prefixing or suffixing depending on environment<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=154–159, 216–217}}</ref> Some verb forms are accompanied by [[ablaut]], and sometimes [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]].<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=161–166, 218–219}}</ref>
Pronominal complement markers cliticize to the verb, with the indirect object preceding the direct object, e.g. /iznz-as-t/ "he sold it to him".<ref>{{cite conference |last1=Louali |first1=Naïma |last2=Philippson |first2=Gerard |year=2003 |title=Vowel apophony and underlying segments in Siwa Berber (Egypt) |conference=Workshop on the Phonology of African Languages (WOPAL) |conferenceurl=http://www.univie.ac.at/linguistics/tagungen/phon02/wopal/wopal_abstracts.htm |publisher=University of Vienna |url=http://www.univie.ac.at/linguistics/tagungen/phon02/wopal/abstracts/wopal_louali_and_philippson.pdf |accessdate=December 20, 2009 }}</ref>
Attributive [[Adjective]]s after the noun they modify, and inflect for number and gender.<ref>{{cite web | title = Berber (Middle Atlas) | work = The World Atlas of Language Structures Online | publisher = Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology & Max Planck Digital Library | location = Munich | date = n.d. | url = http://wals.info/languoid/lect/wals_code_bma | accessdate = December 18, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="s23">{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=23}}</ref> Adjectives may also occur alone, in which case they become an NP.<ref name="s23" /> Practically all adjectives also have a verbal form used for predicative purposes, which behaves just like a normal verb.<ref name="s23" /> <!-- examples from Sadiqi: --> : /argaz amʕdur/ 'the foolish man' (lit. 'man foolish') : /tamtˤut tamʕdur/ 'the foolish woman' <!-- /o/ cannot be phonemic! --> : /irgzen imʕdar/ 'the foolish men' : /tajtʃin timʕdar/ 'the foolish women' : /i-mmuʕdr urgaz/ 'the man is foolish' (lit. '3ps–foolish man') : /argaz i-mmuʕdr-n/ 'the foolish man' [using a non-finite verb]
[[Preposition]]s include {{IPA|/xf/}} ('on'), {{IPA|/qbl/}} ('before'), {{IPA|/ɣr/}} ('to'), and the proclitics {{IPA|/n/}} ('of') and {{IPA|/d/}} ('with, and').<ref group="nb">{{IPA|/n/}} and {{IPA|/d/}} assimilate to some initial consonants: e.g. {{IPA|/ʃa lːħlib/}} 'some milk'), {{IPA|/aɣjul tːfunast/}} 'the donkey and the cow'.</ref> These may take pronominal suffixes. Some prepositions require the following noun to be in the construct state, while others do not.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|pp=123–125}}</ref>
=== Syntax === Word order is usually [[verb–subject–object|VSO]] (with the subject in construct state) but sometimes is [[subject–verb–object|SVO]] (with the subject in free state), e.g. ({{IPA|/ifːɣ umaziɣ/}} vs. {{IPA|/amaziɣ ifːɣ/}} 'the Berber went out').<ref name="am295">{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=295}}</ref> Tamazight also exhibits [[pro-drop]] behavior. <ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Stoyanova|2004|p=172}}</ref>
Tamazight may use a [[null copula]],<ref name="inalco_syntax">{{cite web|last=Chaker |first=Salem |title=La Syntaxe de la Langue Berbere |publisher=[[INALCO]] |location=Paris |date=n.d. |url=http://www.inalco.fr/crb/crb_2/fiches_thema/berbere_syntaxe.htm |accessdate=December 18, 2009 |language=fr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081130154407/http://www.inalco.fr/crb/crb_2/fiches_thema/berbere_syntaxe.htm |archivedate=November 30, 2008 }}</ref> but the word {{IPA|/ɡ/}} 'to be, to do' can function as a copula in Ayt Ayache, especially in structures preceded by /aj/ 'who, which, what'.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971a|p=298}}</ref>
wh- questions are always [[cleft sentence|cleft]]s, and multiple wh-questions<ref group="nb">such as the English "who saw what?", see {{Harvcoltxt|Stoyanova|2004|pp=174–175}}</ref> do not occur.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{Harvcoltxt|Stoyanova|2008|p=105}}</ref> Consequently, Tamazight's clefting, relativisation, and wh-interrogation contribute to anti-agreement effects,<ref group= "nb">when the verb does not agree with, or agrees in a relative manner with wh-words, see {{Harvcoltxt|Richards|2004|p=18}}.</ref> similar to Shilha,<ref name="ReferenceB" /> and causes deletion of the verbal person marker in certain situations.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Richards|2004|p=19}}</ref>
== Vocabulary ==
As a result of relatively intense [[language contact]], Central Atlas Tamazight has a large stratum of Arabic loans. Many borrowed words in Berber also have native synonyms, e.g. /lbab/ or /tiflut/ 'door', the latter used more in rural areas.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=25">{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=25}}</ref> The contact was unequal, as [[Moroccan Arabic]] has not borrowed as much from [[Berber languages]],<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|pp=24–25}}</ref> though Berber has contributed to [[Moroccan Arabic|Moroccan]] and [[Algerian Arabic]]s' very reduced vowel systems.<ref name="prasse">{{cite web |title=Interview met Karl-G. Prasse |url=http://www.tawiza.nl/content/awid.php?id=465&sid=2&andra=artikel |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503140413/http://www.tawiza.nl/content/awid.php?id=465&sid=2&andra=artikel |archivedate= May 3, 2008 |accessdate=December 20, 2009 |ref=harv }}</ref>
Arabic loans span a wide range of [[lexical class]]es. Many nouns begin with /l-/, from the Arabic definite prefix, and some Arabic feminines may acquire the native Berber feminine ending /-t/, e.g. /lʕafit/ for /lʕafia/ 'fire'.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=25}}</ref> Many Arabic loans have been integrated into the Tamazight verb lexicon. They adhere fully to inflectional patterns of native stems, and may even undergo ablaut.<ref name="sadiqi25-26">{{Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|pp=25–26}}</ref><ref name="am153">{{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=153}}</ref> Even [[function word]]s are borrowed, e.g. /blli/ or /billa/ 'that', /waxxa/ 'although', /ɣir/ 'just', etc.<ref name="Harvcoltxt|Sadiqi|1986|p=25" />
The first few (1–3 in Ayt Ayache and Ayt Ndhir) cardinal numerals have native Berber and borrowed [[Arabic language|Arabic]] forms.<ref group="nb">In Ayt Ayache the Arabic numerals are only used for counting in order and for production of higher numbers when combined with the tens, see {{Harvcoltxt|Abdel-Massih|1971b|p=22}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Penchoen|1973|p=24}}</ref> All higher cardinals are borrowed from Arabic, consistent with the linguistic universals that the numbers 1–3 are much more likely to be retained, and that a borrowed number generally implies that numbers greater than it are also borrowed. The retention of one is also motivated by the fact that Berber languages near-universally use unity as a determiner.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Souag|2007|p=240}}</ref>
Central Atlas Tamazight uses a bipartate negative construction (e.g. /uriffiɣ ʃa/ 'he did not go out') which apparently was modeled after proximate [[Arabic language|Arabic]] varieties, in a common development known as [[Jespersen's Cycle]].<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Lucas|2007a|p=2}}</ref> It is present in multiple Berber varieties, and is argued to have originated in neighboring Arabic and been adopted by contact.<ref name="jespersen">{{Harvcoltxt|Lucas|2007b|p=1}}</ref>
