{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{Unreliable sources|date=June 2010}} {{update|date=August 2016<!--This article has not been updated to include results of the [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]].-->}} {{essay-like|date=December 2017}} }} {{mergefrom|Climate resilience|date=June 2018}} [[File:Figure 1- Relationships among Risks, Resilience, Hazard Mitigation, and Climate Change Adaptation (27242486244).jpg|thumb|500x500px|Diagram explaining the relationships between risk, hazard mitigation, resilience, and adaptation]] '''Climate change adaptation''' is a response to [[global warming]] (also known as "climate change" or "anthropogenic climate change"), that seeks to reduce the [[vulnerability]] of social and biological systems to relatively sudden change and thus offset the [[effects of global warming]].<ref>[http://unfccc.int/essential_background/glossary/items/3666.php "UNFCCC Glossary of Climate Change Acronyms"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429220912/http://unfccc.int/essential_background/glossary/items/3666.php |date=29 April 2010 }}. Accessed 24 October 2010</ref> Even if emissions are stabilized relatively soon, global warming and its effects should last many years, and adaptation would be necessary to the resulting changes in climate.<ref>Farber, Daniel A. "Adapting to Climate Change: Who Should Pay", 23 FLA. ST. U. J. LAND USE & ENVTL. L. 1, 8 (2007)</ref> Adaptation is especially important in [[developing countries]] since those countries are predicted to bear the brunt of the effects of global warming.<ref>Cole, Daniel A. "Climate Change, Adaptation, and Development", 26 UCLA J. ENVTL. L. & POL'Y 1, 3 (2008)</ref> That is, the capacity and potential for humans to adapt (called [[adaptive capacity]]) is unevenly distributed across different regions and populations, and developing countries generally have less capacity to adapt.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-es.html |title=Executive summary. In (book chapter): Chapter 19: Assessing Key Vulnerabilities and the Risk from Climate Change. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry, O.F. Canziani, J.P. Palutikof, P.J. van der Linden and C.E. Hanson, Eds.)|authors=Schneider, S.H., S. Semenov, A. Patwardhan, I. Burton, C.H.D. Magadza, M. Oppenheimer, A.B. Pittock, A. Rahman, J.B. Smith, A. Suarez and F. Yamin|year=2007|publisher=Print version: [[Cambridge University Press]], Cambridge, UK. This version: IPCC website|isbn=978-0-521-88010-7|accessdate=2010-04-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100502171249/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch19s19-es.html| archivedate= 2 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Furthermore, the degree of adaptation correlates to the situational focus on environmental issues.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = To What Extent is Business Responding to Climate Change? Evidence from a Global Wine Producer|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10551-011-0919-5|journal = Journal of Business Ethics|date = 15 June 2011|issn = 0167-4544|pages = 421–432|volume = 104|issue = 3|doi = 10.1007/s10551-011-0919-5|language = en|first = Jeremy|last = Galbreath}}</ref> Therefore, adaptation requires the situational assessment of sensitivity and vulnerability to environmental impacts.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = An assessment of climate change impacts and adaptation for the Torres Strait Islands, Australia|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-009-9756-2|journal = Climatic Change|date = 11 December 2009|issn = 0165-0009|pages = 405–433|volume = 102|issue = 3–4|doi = 10.1007/s10584-009-9756-2|language = en|first = Donna|last = Green|first2 = Lisa|last2 = Alexander|first3 = Kathy|last3 = Mclnnes|first4 = John|last4 = Church|first5 = Neville|last5 = Nicholls|first6 = Neil|last6 = White}}</ref>
Adaptive capacity is closely linked to [[social development|social]] and [[economic development]] according to the [[IPCC]].<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms4.html|title=4. Adaptation and mitigation options. In (book section): Summary for Policymakers. In: Climate Change 2007: Synthesis Report. Contribution of Working Groups I, II and III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (Core Writing Team, Pachauri, R.K and Reisinger, A. (eds.))|author=IPCC|year=2007|publisher=Print version: IPCC, Geneva, Switzerland. This version: IPCC website|isbn=92-9169-122-4|accessdate=2010-04-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100501175206/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spms4.html| archivedate= 1 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The economic costs of adaptation to climate change are likely to cost billions of dollars annually for the next several decades, though the amount of money needed is unknown. Donor countries promised an annual $100 billion by 2020 through the [[Green Climate Fund]] for developing countries to adapt to climate change. However, while the fund was set up during [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP16 in Cancún]], concrete pledges by developed countries have not been forthcoming.<ref>[http://www.dandc.eu/articles/220605/index.en.shtml D+C Development and Cooperation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012042541/http://www.dandc.eu/articles/220605/index.en.shtml |date=12 October 2012 }}</ref><ref name="International_Adaptation_Finance">{{Citation |year = 2008 |title = International Adaptation Finance: The Need for an Innovative and Strategic Approach 4 (Oxford Institute for Energy Studies, Working Paper) |author = Benito Müller |format = PDF |url = http://www.eed.de/fix/files/doc/2008_BMueller_int_adapatation_finance.pdf |accessdate = 2010-10-24 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120229175020/http://www.eed.de/fix/files/doc/2008_BMueller_int_adapatation_finance.pdf |archivedate = 29 February 2012 |df = }}</ref> The adaptation challenge grows with the magnitude and the rate of climate change.
Another response to climate change is known as [[climate change mitigation]].<ref>{{cite book|year=2007|title=Glossary J-P. In (book section): Annex I. In: Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz et al. (eds.))|publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website|isbn=978-0-521-88011-4|author=Verbruggen, A. (ed.)|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/annex1sglossary-j-p.html|accessdate=2010-04-23|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503041746/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/annex1sglossary-j-p.html|archivedate=3 May 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> It advocates to reduce [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) emissions or enhance the removal of these gases from [[Atmosphere of Earth|the atmosphere]] (through [[carbon sink]]s).<ref>[url=<nowiki>http://unfccc.int/essential_background/</nowiki>{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} glossary/items/3666.php "UNFCCC Glossary of Climate Change Acronyms"]. Accessed 24 October 2010</ref> Even the most effective reductions in emissions, however, would not prevent further climate change impacts, making the need for adaptation unavoidable.<ref name=":2">{{cite book|year=2007|title=Executive summary. In (book chapter): Inter-relationships between adaptation and mitigation. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry et al. Eds.)|publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website|isbn=978-0-521-88010-7|author=Klein, R.J.T. |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch18s18-es.html|accessdate=2010-04-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421032759/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch18s18-es.html| archivedate= 21 April 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> A study has concluded, with very high confidence, that in the absence of mitigation efforts, the effects of climate change would reach such a magnitude as to make adaptation impossible for some natural [[ecosystem]]s.<ref name=":2" /> Others are concerned that climate adaptation programs might interfere with the existing development programs and thus lead to [[unintended consequences]] for vulnerable groups.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Misra|first=Manoj|date=29 February 2016|title=Smallholder agriculture and climate change adaptation in Bangladesh: questioning the technological optimism|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/17565529.2016.1145101|journal=Climate and Development|volume=0|issue=0|pages=1–11|doi=10.1080/17565529.2016.1145101|issn=1756-5529}}</ref> For human systems, the economic and [[social cost]]s of unmitigated climate change would be very high.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Opperman|first=Jeffrey J.|last2=Galloway|first2=Gerald E.|last3=Fargione|first3=Joseph|last4=Mount|first4=Jeffrey F.|last5=Richter|first5=Brian D.|last6=Secchi|first6=Silvia|date=11 December 2009|title=Sustainable Floodplains Through Large-Scale Reconnection to Rivers|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/326/5959/1487|journal=Science|volume=326|issue=5959|pages=1487–1488|doi=10.1126/science.1178256|issn=0036-8075|pmid=20007887}}</ref>
==Effects of global warming== {{Main|Effects of global warming}} The projected effects for the [[Environment (biophysical)|environment]] and for [[civilization]] are numerous and varied. The main effect is an increasing global average temperature. The average surface temperature could increase by 3 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit (approximately 1.67 to 5.56 degrees Celsius) by the end of the century if carbon emissions aren't reduced.<ref>{{cite web|title=Climate Change Impacts|url=http://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/urgentissues/global-warming-climate-change/threats-impacts/higher-temperatures.xml|publisher=The Nature Conservancy|accessdate=2013-10-31}}</ref> This causes a variety of secondary effects, namely, changes in patterns of precipitation, rising sea levels, [[climate change and agriculture|altered patterns of agriculture]], increased [[extreme weather]] events, the expansion of the range of tropical diseases, and the opening of new marine trade routes.
Potential effects include [[sea level rise]] of {{Nowrap|110 to 770 mm}} {{Nowrap|(0.36 to 2.5 feet)}} between 1990 and 2100, [[Climate change and agriculture|repercussions to agriculture]], [[Shutdown of thermohaline circulation|possible slowing of the thermohaline circulation]], reductions in the [[ozone layer]], increased intensity and frequency of extreme weather events, [[Ocean acidification|lowering]] of ocean [[pH]], and the spread of [[tropical disease]]s such as [[malaria]] and [[dengue fever]].
A summary of probable effects and recent understanding can be found in the report made for the [[IPCC Third Assessment Report]] by Working Group II.<ref>{{cite web |title = Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |url = http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/index.htm |publisher = [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] |date = 16 February 2001 |accessdate = 2007-03-14 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070303133040/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/index.htm |archivedate = 3 March 2007 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> The 2007 contribution of Working Group II detailing the impacts of global warming for the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] has been summarized for policymakers.<ref>{{cite web |title = Summary for Policymakers |work = Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Working Group II Contribution to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Fourth Assessment Report |url = http://www.ipcc.ch/SPM13apr07.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070508192715/http://www.ipcc.ch/SPM13apr07.pdf |archivedate = 8 May 2007 |format = PDF |publisher = [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] |date = 13 April 2007 |accessdate = 2007-05-07}}</ref>
Adaptation is handicapped by uncertainty over the effects of global warming on specific locations such as the [[Southwestern United States]] or phenomena such as the [[Indian monsoon]] predicted to increase in frequency and intensity.<ref name=CD38>{{cite journal|last=Deser|first=Clara|author2=Adam Phillips|author3=Vincent Bourdette|author4=Haiyan Teng|title=Uncertainty in climate change projections: the role of internal variability|journal=Climate Dynamics|date=31 December 2010|volume=38|pages=527–546|doi=10.1007/s00382-010-0977-x|url=http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/cas/cdeser/Docs/deser.internal_variab.climdyn10.pdf|accessdate=23 March 2013|quote=Uncertainty in future climate change presents a key challenge for adaptation planning.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301081648/http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/cas/cdeser/Docs/deser.internal_variab.climdyn10.pdf|archivedate=1 March 2014|df=}}</ref>
==Complementary to mitigation==
[[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]] Working Group II,<ref name="wg2">{{cite web |url=http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/010.htm |title=Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability |publisher=Grida.no |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107193527/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/010.htm |archivedate=7 January 2010 |df= }}</ref> the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]],<ref>{{cite book | title=Policy Implications of Greenhouse Warming: Mitigation, Adaptation, and the Science Base | author=Engineering, and Public Policy (U.S.) Panel on Policy Implications of Greenhouse Warming Committee on Science | publisher=[[National Academies Press]] | isbn=0-309-04386-7 | year=1992 | url=http://books.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=1605 | accessdate=2007-04-14 | page=944| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070302040303/http://books.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=1605| archivedate= 2 March 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> the United Nations Disaster Risk Reduction Office,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unisdr.org/files/23647_themesandissuesindisasterriskreduct.pdf|title=Themes and Issues in Disaster Risk Reduction|publisher=UNISDR |accessdate=2012-08-02}}</ref> and other science policy experts<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/02/070207171745.htm |title=Adaptation To Global Climate Change Is An Essential Response To A Warming Planet |date=8 February 2007 |accessdate=2010-01-06}}</ref> agree that while mitigating the emission of greenhouse gases is important, adaptation to the effects of global warming will still be necessary. Some, like the UK [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]], worry that mitigation efforts will largely fail.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7888994.stm | work=BBC News | title=CO2 reduction treaties useless | date=13 February 2009 | accessdate=2010-04-23 | first=Sarah | last=Mukherjee}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imeche.org/media/press/ |title=2010 Releases |publisher=[[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209041437/http://www.imeche.org/media/press |archivedate=9 February 2010 }}</ref> The IPCC group points out that the world's ability to mitigate global warming is an economic and political challenge. Given that greenhouse gas levels are already elevated, the lag of decades between emissions and some impacts, and the significant economic and political challenges of success, the IPCC group points out that it is uncertain how much climate change ''will'' be mitigated.<ref name="wg2" />
[[Developing countries]] are the least able to adapt to climate change. Doing so depends on such factors as wealth, technology, education, infrastructure, access to resources, management capabilities, acceptance of the existence of climate change and the consequent need for action, and sociopolitical will.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Distribution Impacts of Climate Change and Disasters: Concepts and Cases|last=Ruth|first=M.|last2=Ibarrarian|first2=M. E.|publisher=Edward Elgar|year=2009|isbn=|location=Northampton|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
After assessing the literature on [[sustainability]] and climate change scientists concluded with high confidence that up to the year 2050, an effort to cap GHG emissions at 550 ppm would benefit developing countries significantly.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch20s20-es.html|title=Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry et al., (eds.))|author=Yohe, G.W.|publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. Web version: IPCC website|year=2007|isbn=978-0-521-88010-7|contribution=Executive summary. In (book chapter): Perspectives on climate change and sustainability|accessdate=2010-05-15|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502173108/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch20s20-es.html|archivedate=2 May 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> This was judged to be especially the case when combined with enhanced adaptation. By 2100, however, it was still judged likely that there would be significant climate change impacts. This was judged to be the case even with aggressive mitigation and significantly enhanced adaptive capacity.
The IPCC group also pointed out that climate change adaptation measures can reinforce and be reinforced by efforts to promote [[sustainable development]] and reduce poverty.<ref name="wg2" />
==Costs and international funding== {{very long|date=August 2016}}
===Cost of adaptation vs. mitigation=== {{See also|Economics of global warming#Trade offs}}
Adaptation and mitigation can be viewed as two competing policy responses, with tradeoffs between the two. The other tradeoff is with climate change impacts. In practice, however, the actual tradeoffs are debatable.<ref>{{cite book |year = 2001 |title = 1.4.4.2. Synergies and Tradeoffs between Adaptation and Mitigation. In (book chapter): Overview of Impacts, Adaptation, and Vulnerability to Climate Change. In: Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (J.J. McCarthy et al. Eds.) |publisher = Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: GRID-Arendal website |isbn = 0-521-80768-9 |author = Schneider, S. |url = http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/062.htm#1442 |accessdate = 2010-01-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141021012207/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/062.htm#1442 |archivedate = 21 October 2014 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> This is because the people who bear emission reduction costs or benefits are often different from those who pay or benefit from adaptation measures.
[[Economist]]s, using [[cost-benefit analysis]], have attempted to calculate an "optimal" balance of the costs and benefits between climate change impacts, adaptation, and mitigation.<ref>{{cite book |year = 2001 |title = 10.4.2.1 Economic Considerations. In (book chapter): Decision-making Frameworks. In: Climate Change 2001: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz et al. Eds.) |publisher = Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: GRID-Arendal website |isbn = 978-0-521-01502-8 |author = Toth, F.L. |url = http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/384.htm |accessdate = 2010-01-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131207020236/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg3/384.htm |archivedate = 7 December 2013 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> There are difficulties in doing this calculation, for example, future climate change damages are uncertain, as are the future costs of adaptation.
Also, deciding what "optimal" is depends on [[value judgement]]s made by the economist doing the study (Azar, 1998).<ref>{{cite journal |year = 1998 |title = Are Optimal CO<sub>2</sub> Emissions Really Optimal? Four Critical Issues for Economists in the Greenhouse |author = Azar, C. |journal = Environmental and Resource Economics |volume = 11 |issue = 3–4 |pages = 301–315 |url = http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/azar_1998_four_crucial_issues.pdf |accessdate = 2009-01-10 |doi = 10.1023/A:1008235326513 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120316140445/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/azar_1998_four_crucial_issues.pdf |archivedate = 16 March 2012 |df = }}</ref> For example, how to value impacts occurring in different regions and different times, and "non-market" impacts, e.g., damages to ecosystems.<ref>{{cite book |year = 2001 |title = 19.5.1. Aggregate Analysis: An Assessment. In (book chapter): Vulnerability to Climate Change and Reasons for Concern: A Synthesis. In: Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (J.J. McCarthy et al. Eds.) |publisher = Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: GRID-Arendal website |isbn = 0-521-80768-9 |author = Smith, J.B. |url = http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm#1951 |accessdate = 2010-01-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100224073153/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/676.htm#1951 |archivedate = 24 February 2010 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Economics cannot provide definitive answers to these questions over valuation, and some valuations may be viewed as being controversial (Banuri ''et al.'', 1996, pp. 87, 99).<ref name=banuri>{{cite book |year=1996 |author=Banuri, T. |title=Equity and Social Considerations. In: Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (J.P. Bruce et al. Eds.) |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |isbn=978-0-521-56854-8 |doi=10.2277/0521568544 }}</ref>
Some reviews indicate that policymakers are uncomfortable with using the results of this type of economic analysis.<ref>{{cite book |year=2007 |title=18.5 Inter-relationships in a climate policy portfolio. In (book chapter): Inter-relationships between adaptation and mitigation. In: Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry et al. Eds.) |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |isbn=978-0-521-88010-7 |author=Klein, R.J.T. |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch18s18-5.html |accessdate=2010-04-06 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100502170442/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch18s18-5.html| archivedate= 2 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> This is due to the uncertainties surrounding cost estimates for climate change damages, adaptation, and mitigation. Another type of analysis is based on a [[risk]]-based approach to the problem. It has been argued that adaptation could play an important role in [[climate policy]], but not in an explicit trade-off against mitigation.<ref name=":2" />
===Cost estimates and international aid=== Many scientists, policy makers, and the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] have agreed that disadvantaged nations need to do more to adapt to climate change, especially highly populated regions of developing countries with low [[adaptive capacity]].
The [[United Nations Development Programme]] estimated that an additional USD $86 billion per year would be needed{{where|date=August 2016}} in 2015.<ref>Page 26 [http://hdr.undp.org/en/media/HDR_20072008_Summary_English.pdf Human Development Report 2007/08] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821073604/http://hdr.undp.org/en/media/HDR_20072008_Summary_English.pdf |date=21 August 2010 }} United Nations Development Programme</ref>
According to [[UNFCCC]] estimates in 2007, costs of adaptation to climate change would cost $49–171 billion per year globally by 2030,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pubs.iied.org/pdfs/11501IIED.pdf|title=Assessing the Costs of Adaptation to Climate Change|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> of which a significant share of the additional investment and financial flows, USD $28–67 billion would be needed in 2030 in [[non-Annex I Parties]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/publications/financial_flows.pdf|title=UNFCCC: INVESTMENT AND FINANCIAL FLOWS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE|last=|first=|date=2007|website=UNFCCC|access-date=January 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>Point 26 [http://unfccc.int/files/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/application/pdf/executive_summary.pdf INVESTMENT AND FINANCIAL FLOWS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511110710/http://unfccc.int/files/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/application/pdf/executive_summary.pdf |date=11 May 2012 }} UNFCCC</ref> This represents a doubling of current [[official development assistance]] (ODA).
This estimate has been critiqued by some scientists who argues that the UNFCCC estimate underestimates the cost of adaptation to climate change by a factor of 2 or 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eprints.soton.ac.uk/73760/ |title=Assessing the costs of adaptation to climate change: a review of the UNFCCC and other recent estimates |publisher=ePrints Soton |date=27 March 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-29}}</ref> Moreover, sectors such as tourism, mining, energy, and retail were not included in the UNFCCC estimate.
The more recent World Bank Study, "Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change", found that the costs of adaptation would be in the range of $75–100 billion per year between 2010 and 2050; with higher estimates under the wetter global scenario than the drier scenario, assuming that warming will be about 2 degrees by 2050.<ref>{{cite web | last = [[World Bank]] | title = The Cost to Developing Countries of Adapting to Climate Change. New Methods and Estimates. Consultation Draft. | year = 2010 | url = http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTCC/Resources/EACC-june2010.pdf | accessdate = 2010-07-22}}</ref>
The benefits of strong, early action on [[mitigation of global warming|mitigation]] considerably outweigh the costs.<ref>[https://www.un.org/wcm/webdav/site/climatechange/shared/Documents/Background_Paper.pdf Note from the UN Secretary General regarding the Summit on Climate Change] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026104605/http://www.un.org/wcm/webdav/site/climatechange/shared/Documents/Background_Paper.pdf |date=26 October 2012 }} 22 September 2009</ref> The [[Copenhagen Accord]] was agreed on in order to create a commitment by developed countries to provide:<ref name=ODI/> {{quote|text=new and additional resources...approaching USD $30 billion for the period 2010- 2012 with balanced allocation between adaptation and mitigation... [and] in the context of meaningful mitigation actions and transparency on implementation, developed countries commit to a goal of mobilizing jointly USD$100 billion a year by 2020 to address the needs of developing countries.|sign=[[Copenhagen Accord]]}} However, a key point of contention between states at the [[UNFCC]] [[Copenhagen Climate Summit]] was who was to foot the bill and if aid is to be given, how is it to affect other levels of [[development aid]].<ref name=ODI>Jessica Brown, Neil Bird and Liane Schalatek (2010) [http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=4931&title=climate-finance-additionality-definitions-implications Climate finance additionality: emerging definitions and their implications] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120803075037/http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=4931&title=climate-finance-additionality-definitions-implications |date=3 August 2012 }} [[Overseas Development Institute]]</ref> The concept of '''additionality''' has thus arisen and the [[European Union|EU]] has asked its member states to come up with definitions of what they understand additionality to mean, the four main definitions are:<ref name=ODI/> # Climate finance classified as aid, but additional to (over and above) the [[Millennium Development Goals#Controversy over funding of 0.7% of GNI|0.7% ODA target]]; # Increase on previous year's [[Official Development Assistance]] (ODA) spent on climate change mitigation; # Rising ODA levels that include climate change finance but where it is limited to a specified percentage; and # Increase in climate finance not connected to ODA. The main point being that there is a conflict between the OECD states budget deficit cuts, the need to help developing countries adapt to develop sustainably and the need to ensure that funding does not come from cutting aid to other important [[Millennium Development Goals]].<ref name=ODI/> This is important, because international development through the sustainable (or millennium) development goals may be essential for a long-term solution to climate change <ref name=Webster2018>{{cite journal|last1=A.J.Webster|title=A global consumer-led strategy to tackle climate change|date=July 2018|url=https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.03364}}</ref>.
===International aid mechanisms===
{{As of|2010}}, the aggregate of current climate change adaptation programs will not raise enough money to fund adaptation to climate change.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:GtE3kdqAqg0J:unfccc.int/files/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/application/pdf/executive_summary.pdf+unfccc+executive+summary&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShLpkr2HfiGDHpdJbmhVg8A1aPzMbnVQ-2qUKpKDFowHH5CWdLkipNvuEsNM_5Gmsw0H6qGyQlz6wLIVd6HQByvaNdmnazays1SKNkupFVZKvRZRMUY8W98Wa1xnUPfDkZ0h8OM&sig=AHIEtbRGW-W5dh6NF-k3M9gGPciHwWHHCg |title=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, Investment and Financial Flows to Address Climate Change, Executive Summary ¶ 11 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> There are, however, several programs and proposals to finance adaptation to climate change in [[Developing country|developing countries]]. The [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) runs a program called the [[Global Environmental Facility]], which provides some funding for adaptation to [[least developed countries]] and [[Small Island Developing States|small island states]].<ref name="UNFCCC Adaptation">{{cite web |url=http://unfccc.int/adaptation/items/4159.php |title=UNFCCC Adaptation |accessdate=2010-04-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100429214010/http://unfccc.int/adaptation/items/4159.php| archivedate= 29 April 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Under the GEF umbrella, the GEF Trust Fund, the [http://www.thegef.org/gef/LDCF Least Developed Countries Fund (LDCF)], and the [http://unfccc.int/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/special_climate_change_fund/items/3657.php Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF)] operate to carry out the climate change adaptation financing goals of the GEF.<ref name="UNFCCC Adaptation"/>
Another UNFCCC mechanism is [[The Adaptation Fund]], as a result of negotiations during [[COP15]] and [[COP16]], which provides funds for projects that prove to have additional benefits for adaptation to climate change. The [[Clean Development Mechanism]] (CDM), set up as part of the [[Kyoto Protocol]] to the Framework Convention, is the main source of income for the UNFCCC Adaptation Fund. This fund was established in 2007.<ref>{{cite book |year = 2010 |author = World Bank |title = World Development Report 2010: Development and Climate Change |publisher = The [[International Bank for Reconstruction and Development]] / The [[World Bank]], 1818 H Street NW, Washington DC 20433 |url = http://go.worldbank.org/BKLQ9DSDU0 |isbn = 978-0-8213-7987-5 |doi = 10.1596/978-0-8213-7987-5 |accessdate = 2010-04-06 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100410171605/http://go.worldbank.org/BKLQ9DSDU0 |archivedate = 10 April 2010 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> The CDM is subject to a 2% levy, which could raise between $300 million and $600 million over the 2008-12 period. The actual amount raised will depend on the carbon price. {{as of|2010|August|}}, The Adaptation Fund has not yet disbursed any funding;{{update inline|date=August 2016}} a call for proposals was issued in April 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adaptation-fund.org/howtoapply |title=How to Apply |publisher=Adaptation Fund |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727030703/http://www.adaptation-fund.org/howtoapply |archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> UNFCCC funding for Least Developed Countries includes development of a [[National Adaptation Programme of Action]], which prioritizes requests to fund specific adaptation projects.
There are several other climate change adaptation finance proposals, most of which employ [[official development assistance]] or ODA.<ref name="International_Adaptation_Finance"/> These proposals range from a World Bank program, to proposals involving auctioning of carbon allowances, to a global carbon or transportation tax, to compensation-based funding.<ref name="International_Adaptation_Finance"/> Other proposals suggest using market-based mechanisms, rather than ODA, such as the Higher Ground Foundation's vulnerability reduction credit (VRC™)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehighergroundfoundation.org/ |title=Financing Climate Adaptation Measures Using a Credit Trading Mechanism: Initial Considerations |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-09-21}}</ref> or a program similar to the [[Clean Development Mechanism]],<ref>{{citation |ssrn=1685027 |title=Call for a Pilot Program for Market-Based Adaptation Funding |author=Matthew Baca |accessdate=}}</ref> to raise private money for climate change adaptation. The [[Copenhagen Accord]], the most recent global climate change agreement, commits developed countries to goal of sending $100 billion per year to developing countries in assistance for climate change mitigation and adaptation through 2020.<ref>{{cite conference |url=http://unfccc.int/meetings/cop_15/items/5257.php |title=Conference of the Parties to the Framework Convention on Climate Change|location=[[Copenhagen]]|date= 7–18 December 2009 |id=un document= FCCC/CP/2009/L.7 |accessdate=2010-10-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101018074452/http://unfccc.int/meetings/cop_15/items/5257.php| archivedate= 18 October 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> This agreement, while not binding, would dwarf current amounts dedicated to adaptation in developing countries. This climate change fund is called the [[Green Climate Fund]] from the [[2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/green_climate_fund/items/5869.php |title=Transitional Committee for the design of the Green Climate Fund |publisher=Unfccc.int |accessdate=2011-11-18}}</ref>
===Integration with development aid=== Many [[Developing country|developing countries]] prioritize economic development over addressing the issue of climate change, as they are more concerned about pre-existing problems such as poverty, malnutrition, food insecurity,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y4671e/y4671e06.htm |title=Chapter 2. Food security: concepts and measurement[21] |publisher=Fao.org |accessdate=2010-08-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100826025404/http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y4671e/y4671e06.htm| archivedate= 26 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> availability of drinking water, indebtedness, illiteracy, unemployment, local resource conflicts, and lower technological development. It has even been argued that international development through the sustainable development goals, is essential for a long-term solution to climate change <ref name=Webster2018 />. On the other hand, climate change threatens to exacerbate or stall progress on fixing some of these pre-existing problems. Advocates have thus proposed integrating climate change adaptation into poverty reduction programs.<ref>[http://www.ids.ac.uk/go/bookshop/ids-bulletin/ids-bulletin-39-2008 Poverty in a Changing Climate] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513222525/http://www.ids.ac.uk/go/bookshop/ids-bulletin/ids-bulletin-39-2008 |date=13 May 2012 }} [[Institute of Development Studies]] Bulletin 39(4), September 2008</ref>
==Considerations and general recommendations== {{very long|date=August 2016}}
===Principles for effective policy=== Adaptive [[Public policy|policy]] can occur at the global, national, or local scale, with outcomes dependent on the political will in that area.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|date=2008-02-01|title=Does public policy support or undermine climate change adaptation? Exploring policy interplay across different scales of governance|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959378007000611|journal=Global Environmental Change|language=en|volume=18|issue=1|pages=180–191|doi=10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2007.08.002|issn=0959-3780}}</ref> Scheraga and Grambsch<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/eims/global/clim_res.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-04-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910233126/http://www.epa.gov/eims/global/clim_res.pdf |archivedate=10 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> identify 9 fundamental principles to be considered when designing adaptation policy.
# The effects of climate change vary by region. # The effects of climate change may vary across demographic groups. # Climate change poses both risks and opportunities. # The effects of climate change must be considered in the context of multiple stressors and factors, which may be as important to the design of adaptive responses as the sensitivity of the change. # Adaptation comes at a cost. # Adaptive responses vary in effectiveness, as demonstrated by current efforts to cope with climate variability. # The systemic nature of climate impacts complicates the development of adaptation policy. # Maladaptation can result in negative effects that are as serious as the climate-induced effects that are being avoided. # Many opportunities for adaptation make sense whether or not the effects of climate change are realized.
Scheraga and Grambsch make it clear that climate change policy is impeded by the high level of variance surrounding climate change impacts as well as the diverse nature of the problems they face.
Adaptation can mitigate the adverse impacts of [[climate change]], but it will incur costs and will not prevent all damage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2011/06/06/economics-adaptation-climate-change|title=Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change|work=World Bank|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref> The IPCC points out that many adverse effects of climate change are not changes in the average conditions, but changes in the variation or the extremes of conditions.<ref name="wg2" /> For example, the average sea level in a port might not be as important as the height of water during a storm surge (which causes flooding); the average rainfall in an area might not be as important as how frequent and severe [[Drought|droughts]] and extreme precipitation events become.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.noaa.gov/resource-collections/climate-change-impacts|title=Climate change impacts {{!}} National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|website=www.noaa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> Additionally, effective adaptive policy can be difficult to implement because policymakers are rewarded more for enacting short-term change, rather than long-term planning.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Environmental Politics and Policy|last=Rosenbaum|first=Walter A.|publisher=CQ Press|year=2017|isbn=978-1-4522-3996-5|location=Thousand Oaks, CA|pages=}}</ref> Since the impacts of climate change are generally not seen in the short-term, this means that policymakers have less incentive to act upon those potential outcomes. Furthermore, these problems (both the causes and effects of climate change) are occurring on a global scale, which has caused the United Nations to lead global policy efforts such as the [[Kyoto Protocol]] and [[Paris Agreement]], in addition to creating a body of research through the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]], in order to create a global framework for adapting to and combatting climate change.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/en/sections/issues-depth/climate-change/|title=Climate Change|website=www.un.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> However, the vast majority of climate change adaptation and [[Mitigation of climate change|mitigation]] policies are being implemented on a more local scale due to the fact that different regions must adapt differently to climate change and because national and global policies are often more challenging to enact.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wood|first=Robert|last2=Hultquist|first2=Andy|last3=Romsdahl|first3=Rebecca|date=2014-11-01|title=An Examination of Local Climate Change Policies in the Great Plains|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/267396181_An_Examination_of_Local_Climate_Change_Policies_in_the_Great_Plains|journal=Review of Policy Research|volume=31|doi=10.1111/ropr.12103}}</ref>
===Criteria for assessing responses=== James Titus, project manager for sea level rise at the U.S. [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]], identifies the following criteria that policy makers should use in assessing responses to global warming:<ref>{{cite web |first=James |last=Titus |title=Strategies for Adaptation to Global Warming |url=http://epa.gov/climatechange/effects/downloads/adapting_japa.pdf}}</ref>
* Economic [[Efficiency]]: Will the initiative yield benefits substantially greater than if the resources were applied elsewhere? * Flexibility: Is the strategy reasonable for the entire range of possible changes in temperatures, precipitation, and sea level? * Urgency: Would the strategy be successful if implementation were delayed ten or twenty years? * [[Low cost|Low Cost]]: Does the strategy require minimal resources? * Equity: Does the strategy unfairly benefit some at the expense of other regions, generations, or economic classes? * Institutional feasibility: Is the strategy acceptable to the public? Can it be implemented with existing institutions under existing laws? * Unique or Critical Resources: Would the strategy decrease the risk of losing unique environmental or cultural resources? * Health and Safety: Would the proposed strategy increase or decrease the risk of disease or injury? * Consistency: Does the policy support other national state, community, or private goals? * Private v. Public Sector: Does the strategy minimize governmental interference with decisions best made by the private sector?
===Differing time scales===
Adaptation can either occur in anticipation of change (anticipatory adaptation), or be a response to those changes (reactive adaptation).<ref name="uea.ac.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.uea.ac.uk/env/people/adgerwn/Adgeretal2005GEC.pdf |title=Successful adaptation to climate change across scales |doi=10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2004.12.005 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402025816/http://www.uea.ac.uk/env/people/adgerwn/Adgeretal2005GEC.pdf |archivedate=2 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> Most adaptation being implemented at present is responding to current climate trends and variability, for example increased use of [[Snowmaking|artificial snow-making]] in the European Alps. Some adaptation measures, however, are anticipating future climate change, such as the construction of the Confederation Bridge in Canada at a higher elevation to take into account the effect of future sea-level rise on ship clearance under the bridge.<ref name="ipcc.ch" />
Much adaptation takes place in relation to short-term climate variability, however this may cause [[maladaptation]] to longer-term climatic trends. For example, the expansion of irrigation in Egypt into the Western Sinai desert due to a period of higher river flows is a maladaptation when viewed in relation to the longer term projections of drying in the region<ref name="iied.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.iied.org/CC/documents/adapt_to_cc.pdf |title=Adaptation to Climate Change in the Developing World |publisher=Iied.org |date=16 June 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922205501/http://www.iied.org/CC/documents/adapt_to_cc.pdf |archivedate=22 September 2008 |df= }}</ref>). Adaptations at one scale can also create externalities at another by reducing the adaptive capacity of other actors. This is often the case when broad assessments of the costs and benefits of adaptation are examined at smaller scales and it is possible to see that whilst the adaptation may benefit some actors, it has a negative effect on others.<ref name="uea.ac.uk" />
===Traditional coping strategies===
People have always adapted to climatic changes and some community coping strategies already exist, for example changing sowing times or adopting new water-saving techniques.<ref name="iied.org" /> Traditional knowledge and coping strategies must be maintained and strengthened, otherwise adaptive capacity may be weakened as local knowledge of the environment is lost. Strengthening these local techniques and building upon them also makes it more likely that adaptation strategies will be adopted, as it creates more community ownership and involvement in the process.<ref name="ipcc.ch" /> In many cases however this will not be enough to adapt to new conditions which are outside the range of those previously experienced, and new techniques will be needed.<ref name="geog.psu.edu" /> The incremental adaptations which were being implemented are now insufficient as the vulnerabilities and risks of climate change have increased, this causes a need for transformational adaptations which are much larger and costlier.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kates|first1=Robert W.|last2=Travis|first2=William R.|last3=Wilbanks|first3=Thomas J.|title=Transformational adaptation when incremental adaptations to climate change are insufficient|journal=PNAS|date=14 March 2012|volume=109|pages=7156–7161|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/109/19/7156.full|doi=10.1073/pnas.1115521109|pmc=3358899}}</ref> Current development efforts are increasingly focusing on community-based climate change adaptation, seeking to enhance local knowledge, participation and ownership of adaptation strategies.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McNamara |first1=Karen Elizabeth |last2=Buggy |first2=Lisa |title=Community-based climate change adaptation: a review of academic literature |journal=Local Environment: The International Journal of Justice and Sustainability |date=5 August 2016 |pages=1–18 |doi=10.1080/13549839.2016.1216954 |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13549839.2016.1216954?scroll=top&needAccess=true |accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref>

===Enhancing adaptive capacity===
Adaptation can be defined as adjustments of a system to reduce [[vulnerability]] and to increase the resilience of a system to change,<ref name="ipcc.ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg2/ar4-wg2-chapter17.pdf |title=Assessment of adaptation practices, options, constraints and capacity |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-08-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100827182247/http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg2/ar4-wg2-chapter17.pdf| archivedate= 27 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> also known as [[adaptive capacity]]. Those societies that can respond to change quickly and successfully have a high adaptive capacity.<ref name="geog.psu.edu">{{cite web |url=http://www.geog.psu.edu/pdf/Smit_Wandel_GEC.pdf |title=Adaptation, adaptive capacity and vulnerability |doi=10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2006.03.008 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624132408/http://www.geog.psu.edu/pdf/Smit_Wandel_GEC.pdf |archivedate=24 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> High adaptive capacity does not necessarily translate into successful adaptation. For example, the adaptive capacity in Western Europe is high, and the risks of warmer winters increasing the range of livestock diseases was well documented, but many parts of Europe were still badly affected by outbreaks of the [[Bluetongue disease|Bluetongue virus]] in livestock in 2007.
Adaptive capacity is the ability of a system (human, natural or managed) to adjust to climate change (including climate variability and extremes) to moderate potential damages, to take advantage of opportunities, or to cope with consequences.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/annexessglossary-a-d.html|title=Adaptive capacity|chapter=Appendix I. Glossary|ref=harv}}, in {{harvnb|IPCC AR4 WG2|2007}} </ref> Unmitigated climate change (i.e., future climate change without efforts to limit greenhouse gas emissions) would, in the long term, be likely to exceed the capacity of natural, managed and human systems to adapt.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains6-3.html|title=Sec 6.3 Responses to climate change: Robust findings]|chapter=Synthesis report|ref=harv}}, in {{harvnb|IPCC AR4 SYR|2007}} </ref>
It has been found that enhanced adaptive capacity would reduce vulnerability to climate change.<ref>{{cite book |year = 2001 |title = Executive summary. In (book chapter): Adaptation to Climate Change in the Context of Sustainable Development and Equity. In: Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Others have suggested that certain forms of gender inequity should be addressed at the same time;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikiadapt.org/index.php?title=Gender_and_Climate_Change |title=Gender and Climate Change |publisher=[[Stockholm Environment Institute]] WikiADAPT |date=2 July 2009 |accessdate=2010-08-29}}</ref> for example women may have participation in decision-making, or be constrained by lower levels of education.<ref name="ipcc.ch" />
Researchers at the [[Overseas Development Institute]] found that development interventions to increase adaptive capacity have tended not to result in increased [[agency (sociology)|agency]] for local people.<ref>Ludi, E., Jones, L. and Levine, S. (2012) Changing focus? How to take adaptive capacity seriously. ===Agricultural production=== A significant effect of global climate change is the altering of global rainfall patterns, with certain effects on agriculture.<ref name="cep-jennings"> {{cite journal | last = Jennings | first = Paul A. |date=February 2008 | title = Dealing with Climate Change at the Local Level | journal = Chemical Engineering Progress | volume = 104 | issue = 2 | pages = 40–44 | publisher = [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]] | url = http://www.aiche.org/uploadedFiles/CEP/Issues/2008-02/020840.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2008-02-29 }}</ref> Rainfed agriculture constitutes 80% of global agriculture. Many of the 852 million poor people in the world live in parts of Asia and Africa that depend on rainfall to cultivate food crops. Climate change will modify [[rainfall]], [[evaporation]], [[Surface runoff|runoff]], and [[soil moisture]] storage. Extended drought can cause the failure of small and marginal farms with resultant economic, political and social disruption, more so than this currently occurs.
Agriculture of any kind is strongly influenced by the availability of water. Changes in total [[seasonal precipitation]] or in its pattern of variability are both important. The occurrence of [[moisture stress]] during [[flowering]], [[pollination]], and [[grain-filling]] is harmful to most crops and particularly so to [[Maize|corn]], [[soybeans]], and [[wheat]]. Increased [[evaporation]] from the soil and accelerated [[transpiration]] in the plants themselves will cause moisture stress.
Adaptive ideas include: * Taking advantage of global transportation systems to delivering surplus food to where it is needed<ref name="cep-jennings" /> (though this does not help subsistence farmers unless aid is given). * Developing crop varieties with greater [[drought tolerance]]. * Rainwater storage. For example, according to the [[International Water Management Institute]], using small planting basins to 'harvest' water in Zimbabwe has been shown to boost maize yields, whether rainfall is abundant or scarce. And in Niger, they have led to three or fourfold increases in millet yields.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/09/06/us-climate-water-idUSTRE68500820100906 ''Diverse water sources key to food security: report''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901190215/https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/09/06/us-climate-water-idUSTRE68500820100906 |date=1 September 2013 }}, Reuters, 5 September 2010</ref> * Falling back from crops to wild edible fruits, roots and leaves. Promoting the growth of forests can provide these backup food supplies, and also provide watershed conservation, carbon sequestration, and aesthetic value.
====More spending on irrigation==== The [[demand for water]] for [[irrigation]] is projected to rise in a warmer climate, bringing increased competition between agriculture—already the largest consumer of water resources in [[Semi-arid climate|semi-arid regions]]—and urban as well as industrial users. Falling [[water table]]s and the resulting increase in the energy needed to pump water will make the practice of irrigation more expensive, particularly when with drier conditions more water will be required per [[acre]]. Other strategies will be needed to make the most efficient use of water resources. For example, the [[International Water Management Institute]] has suggested five strategies that could help Asia feed its growing population in light of climate change. These are: * Modernising existing irrigation schemes to suit modern methods of farming * Supporting farmers' efforts to find their own water supplies, by tapping into groundwater in a sustainable way * Looking beyond conventional "Participatory Irrigation Management" schemes, by engaging the private sector * Expanding capacity and knowledge * Investing outside the irrigation sector<ref>Mukherji, A. [https://web.archive.org/web/20071102102545/http://www.iwmi.cgiar.org/Publications/Other/index.aspx Revitalising Asia's Irrigation: To sustainably meet tomorrow's food needs] 2009, [[IWMI]] and [[FAO]]</ref>
===Weather control=== Russian and American scientists have in the past tried to control the weather, for example by [[cloud seeding|seeding clouds]] with chemicals to try to produce rain when and where it is needed. A new method being developed involves replicating the [[urban heat island]] effect, where cities are slightly hotter than the countryside because they are darker and absorb more heat. This creates 28% more rain 20–40 miles [[Windward and leeward#mediaviewer/File:Upwind downwind example.png|downwind]] from cities compared to upwind.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/weather/Story/0,2763,1516375,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Spain goes hi-tech to beat drought | first=Dale | last=Fuchs | date=28 June 2005 | accessdate=2010-04-23 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104170020/http://www.guardian.co.uk/weather/Story/0%2C2763%2C1516375%2C00.html | archivedate=4 November 2007 | deadurl=no | df= }}</ref> On the timescale of several decades, new [[weather control]] techniques may become feasible which would allow control of extreme weather such as hurricanes.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lloyd de Vries |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/10/29/tech/main652303.shtml |title=Sapping A Hurricane's Strength, Research Under Way, But Actual Applications Still Decades Away |publisher=CBS News |date=29 October 2004 |accessdate=2010-08-29}}</ref>
The World Meteorological Organization ([[WMO]]) through its Commission for Atmospheric Sciences (CAS) opined in 2007: "Purposeful augmentation of precipitation, reduction of hail damage, dispersion of fog and other types of cloud and storm modifications by cloud seeding are developing technologies which are still striving to achieve a sound scientific foundation and which have to be adapted to enormously varied natural conditions."<ref>[[WMO]] DOCUMENTS ON WEATHER MODIFICATION APPROVED BY THE COMMISSION FOR ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCES MANAGEMENT GROUP, SECOND SESSION, OSLO, NORWAY, 24–26 September 2007 {{cite web |url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/arep/wwrp/new/documents/WM_statement_guidelines_approved.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417160300/http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/arep/wwrp/new/documents/WM_statement_guidelines_approved.pdf |archivedate=17 April 2016 |df= }} - see "STATEMENT ON WEATHER MODIFICATION" and "GUIDELINES FOR THE PLANNING OF WEATHER MODIFICATION ACTIVITIES"</ref>
===Damming glacial lakes=== [[Glacial lake outburst flood]]s may become a bigger concern due to the retreat of glaciers, leaving behind numerous lakes that are impounded by often weak [[terminal moraine]] dams. In the past, the sudden failure of these dams has resulted in localized property damage, injury and deaths. [[Glacial lake]]s in danger of bursting can have their [[moraine]]s replaced with concrete dams (which may also provide hydroelectric power).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://environmentalresearchweb.org/cws/article/news/66280|title=Many hydroelectric plants in Himalayas are at risk from glacial lakes - environmentalresearchweb|website=environmentalresearchweb.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
===Geoengineering=== {{Main|Climate engineering|Solar radiation management}}
IPCC (2007) concluded that [[Climate engineering|geoengineering]] options, such as ocean fertilization to remove CO<sub>2</sub> from the [[atmosphere]], remained largely unproven.<ref>{{cite book |year=2007 |title=C. Mitigation in the short and medium term (until 2030). In (book section): Summary for Policymakers. In: Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz et al. (eds.)) |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |isbn=978-0-521-88011-4 |author=IPCC |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/spmsspm-c.html |accessdate=2010-05-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100502182529/http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/spmsspm-c.html| archivedate= 2 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> It was judged that reliable cost estimates for geoengineering had not been published.
The [[Royal Society]] (2009) published the findings of a study into geoengineering. The authors of the study defined geoengineering as a "deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth's climate system, in order to moderate global warming".<ref>{{cite book |date=September 2009 |author=Royal Society |title=Summary. In (document): Geoengineering the climate: science, governance and uncertainty. RS Policy document 10/09 |url=http://royalsociety.org/Geoengineering-the-climate/ |publisher=The UK Royal Society's website |isbn=978-0-85403-773-5 |accessdate=2010-05-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091202150938/http://royalsociety.org/Geoengineering-the-climate/| archivedate= 2 December 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> According to the study, the safest and most predictable method of moderating climate change is early action to reduce GHG emissions.
Scientists such as [[Ken Caldeira]] and [[Paul Crutzen]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=geoengineering-how-to-cool-earth |title=Geoengineering: How to Cool Earth--At a Price |publisher=Scientific American |date=October 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2009 |author=Robert Kunzig}}</ref> suggest techniques such as: *[[Solar radiation management]] may be seen as an adaptation to global warming.{{According to whom|date=May 2010}} Techniques such as [[space sunshade]], creating [[stratospheric sulfur aerosols]] and painting roofing and paving materials white all fall into this category. *[[Hydrological geoengineering]] - typically seeking to preserve [[sea ice]] or adjust [[thermohaline circulation]] by using methods such as diverting rivers to keep warm water away from [[sea ice]], or tethering [[icebergs]] to prevent them drifting into warmer waters and melting. Though this is an adaptation technique, if it prevents [[Arctic methane release]] it would also be classified as mitigation.
===Migration=== Migration frequently requires would-be migrants to have access to social and financial capital, such as support networks in the chosen destination, and the funds or physical resources to be able to move. It is frequently the last adaptive response households will take when confronted with environmental factors that threaten their livelihoods, and mostly resorted to when other mechanisms to cope have proven unsuccessful.<ref name="Migration and Climate Change">{{cite web|author=Source: Unescopress |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/sv/news/migration_and_climate_change_a_unesco_publication_on_one_of_the_greatest_challenges_facing_our_time/ |title="Migration and Climate Change" A UNESCO publication on one of the greatest challenges facing our time | United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |publisher=Unesco.org |accessdate=2011-11-18}}</ref>
The rhetoric of migration being related to climate change is complex and disputed. However, It is widely accepted that the results of migration events are multi-causal, with the environment being just a factor amongst many. Outside of policy, human rights organizations, expert demographers and environmental climate scientists dominate this debate. Many discussions are based on projections and less with current migration data.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bardsley|first=Douglas K.|last2=Hugo|first2=Graeme J.|date=2010-12-01|title=Migration and climate change: examining thresholds of change to guide effective adaptation decision-making|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11111-010-0126-9|journal=Population and Environment|language=en|volume=32|issue=2–3|pages=238–262|doi=10.1007/s11111-010-0126-9|issn=0199-0039}}</ref> While many migration events can be attributed to sudden environmental change, most migration events are a result of long term environmental changes and do not cause sudden migration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/science/britain-europe-split-land-bridge.html|title=When Britain Split From Europe, in a Big Way |publisher=The New York Times|date=4 April 2017|author=Nicholas Wade}}</ref> Some scholars attribute these events to sudden environmental changes, like natural disasters. Some choose to label it "climate change", which reflects a more long term onset of change, and the human impact element.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Moniruzzaman | first1 = M | year = 2016 | title = Climate and Human Migration: Past Experiences, Future Challenges Robert A.McLeman, Cambridge University Press, New York, 2014, 300 pp. | url = | journal = The Canadian Geographer / Le Géographe Canadien | volume = 60 | issue = 2| pages = e24–e25 | doi = 10.1111/cag.12267 }}</ref>
It is helpful to provide an intersectional approach to this discussion and understand that focusing on climate change as the issue frames the debate in terms of projections, causing the research to be speculative. Migration as tool for climate change adaptation is projected to be a more pressing issue in the decade to come.<ref>Adamo, S. (2008). Addressing environmentally induced population displacements:A delicate task.Background Paper for the Environment Research Network Cyberseminar on Environmentally Induced Population Displacements. Available at <nowiki>http://www.populationenvironmentresearch.org.Cited</nowiki> December 21, 2009.</ref> It is often framed in terms of human rights issues and national security. Migration events are often seen as a failure of the governments or policy making bodies that could not contain or effectively manage environmental changes.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baldwin | first1 = A. | last2 = Fornalé | first2 = E. | year = 2017 | title = Adaptive migration: pluralising the debate on climate change and migration | url = | journal = The Geographical Journal | volume = 183 | issue = 4| pages = 322–328 | doi = 10.1111/geoj.12242 }}</ref> For example, extreme drought events in the Caribbean proliferate movement of peoples because of the lack of water.{{cn|date=August 2018}} This is often seen as a failure on the local governments to provide structural and independent resources. These adaptation failures that have been the topic of concern for many scholars researching this area. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees has been viewed as one of the highest authorities to help those displaced.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ober | first1 = K. | last2 = Sakdapolrak | first2 = P. | year = 2017 | title = How do social practices shape policy? Analysing the field of "migration as adaptation" with Bourdieu's "Theory of Practice | url = | journal = The Geographical Journal | volume = 183 | issue = 4| pages = 359–369 | doi = 10.1111/geoj.12225 }}</ref>
===Insurance=== Insurance spreads the financial impact of flooding and other extreme weather events.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Duus-Otterström | first1 = Göran | last2 = Jagers | first2 = Sverker C. | year = 2011 | title = Why (most) Climate Insurance Schemes are a Bad Idea | url = | journal = Environmental Politics | volume = 20 | issue = 3| pages = 322–339 | doi=10.1080/09644016.2011.573354}}</ref> Although it can be preferable to take a proactive approach to eliminate the cause of the risk, reactive post-harm compensation can be used as a last resort.<ref>Duus 2011, p.323</ref> Access to reinsurance may be a form of increasing the resiliency of cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissre.com/rethinking/climate_and_natural_disaster_risk/Mind_the_risk.html |title=Mind the risk: cities under threat from natural disasters |publisher=SwissRe |accessdate=2014-09-30 }}</ref> Where there are failures in the private insurance market, the public sector can subsidize premiums.<ref>McAneney, J, Crompton, R, McAneney, D, Musulin, R, Walker, G & Pielke Jr, R 2013, "Market-based mechanisms for climate change adaptation: Assessing the potential for and limits to insurance and market based mechanisms for encouraging climate change adaptation." National Climate Change Adaptation Research Facility, Gold Coast, 99 pp.</ref> A study identified key equity issues for policy considerations:<ref>McAneney, et al. 2013, p.99</ref>
* transferring risk to the public purse does not reduce overall risk * governments can spread the cost of losses across time rather than space * governments can force home-owners in low risk areas to cross-subsidize the insurance premiums of those in high risk areas * cross-subsidization is increasingly difficult for private sector insurers operating in a competitive market * governments can tax people to pay for tomorrow's disaster
Government-subsidized insurance, such as the U.S. National Flood Insurance Program, is criticized for providing a [[perverse incentive]] to develop properties in hazardous areas, thereby increasing overall risk.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Holloway | first1 = J.M. | last2 = Burby | first2 = R.J. | year = 1990 | title = The effects of floodplain development controls on residential land values | url = | journal = Land Economics | volume = 66 | issue = 3| pages = 259–271 }}</ref> It is also suggested that insurance can undermine other efforts to increase adaptation, for instance through property level protection and resilience.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=O'Hare|first=Paul|last2=White|first2=Iain|last3=Connelly|first3=Angela|date=1 September 2015|title=Insurance as maladaptation: Resilience and the 'business as usual' paradox|url=http://epc.sagepub.com/content/early/2015/09/01/0263774X15602022|journal=Environment and Planning C: Government and Policy|language=en|pages=0263774X15602022|doi=10.1177/0263774X15602022|issn=0263-774X}}</ref> This behavioral effect may be countered with appropriate land-use policies that limit new construction where current or future climate risks are perceived and/or encourage the adoption of resilient building codes to mitigate potential damages.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bagstad | first1 = Kenneth J. | last2 = Stapleton | first2 = K. | last3 = D'Agostino | first3 = J.R. | year = 2007 | title = Taxes, subsidies, and insurance as drivers of United States coastal development | url = | journal = Ecological Economics | volume = 63 | issue = | pages = 285–298 | doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2006.09.019}}</ref>
==Adaptation measures by region== The [[Netherlands]], along with the [[Philippines]] and [[Japan]] and [[United Nations Environment Programme|United Nations Environment]], launched the [[Global Centre of Excellence on Climate Adaptation]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sdg.iisd.org/news/cop-23-side-events-spotlight-climate-action-champions-link-ndcs-and-sdgs-14-november-highlights/|title=COP 23 Side Events Spotlight Climate Action Champions, Link NDCs and SDGs: 14 November Highlights {{!}} News {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD|last=Hub|first=IISD's SDG Knowledge|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://enb.iisd.org/climate/cop23/excellence-climate-adaptation/14nov.html|title=IISD/ENB+ @ About {{!}} Launch of the Global Centre for Excellence on Climate Adaptation {{!}} 14 November 2017 {{!}} Bonn, DE {{!}} IISD Reporting Services|website=enb.iisd.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbl.nl/en/news/newsitems/2017/launch-global-centre-of-excellence-on-climate-adaptation-on-cop23|title=Launch Global Centre of Excellence on Climate Adaptation on COP23 - PBL Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency|website=www.pbl.nl|language=en|access-date=2018-02-02}}</ref>
Numerous countries, including [[Adaptation to global warming in Australia|Australia]], have held inquiries into and have planned or started adaptation measures.
